quote: Abandon yourself utterly for the love of God, and in this way you will become truly happy.
author: Henry Suso
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Lose yourself wholly; and the more you lose, the more you will find.
author: Catherine of Siena
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let each one remember that he will make progress in all spiritual things only insofar as he rids himself of self-love, self-will, and self-interest.
author: Ignatius Loyola
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I need nothing but God, and to lose myself in the heart of God.
author: Margaret Mary Alacoque
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let us throw ourselves into the ocean of His goodness, where every failing will be canceled and anxiety turned into love.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I wish I could lose myself and never find myself except in God!
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A woman who deliberately destroys a fetus is answerable for murder. And any fine distinction between its being completely formed or unformed is not admissible among us.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There are three distinct comings of the Lord of which I know: His coming to men, His coming into men, and His coming against men.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We don’t walk to God with the feet of our body, nor would wings, if we had them, carry us to Him; but we go to Him by the affections of our soul.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let your afflictions be books to admonish you.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God measures out affliction according to our need.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: One and the same violence of affliction proves, purifies, and melts the good, and condemns, wastes, and casts out the bad.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: You who teach us by sorrow, and wound us in order to heal us, and kill us so that we may not die apart from You.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Why are we sad? Why do we blame God? Evils abound in the world so that the world will fail to seduce us into loving it.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The more we are afflicted in this world, the greater is our assurance in the next; the more we sorrow in the present, the greater will be our joy in the future.
author: Isidore of Seville
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If things always went wrong, no one could endure it; if things always went well, everyone would become arrogant.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Tribulation is a gift from God—one that He especially gives His special friends.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Without the burden of afflictions it is impossible to reach the height of grace. The gift of grace increases as the struggles increase.
author: Rose of Lima
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Whenever anything disagreeable or displeasing happens to you, remember Christ crucified and be silent.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: See to it that you’re not suddenly saddened by the adversities of this world, for you don’t know the good they bring, being ordained in the judgments of God for the everlasting joy of the elect.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Many would be willing to have afflictions provided that they be not inconvenienced by them.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is not enough to be afflicted because God wills it; but we must be so as He wills it, when He wills it, for as long as He wills it, and exactly in the manner in which it pleases Him.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Should we not adore God’s will in profound submission, and lovingly kiss the rod with which He reproves His elect?
author: Jane Frances de Chantal
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When men wish for old age for themselves, what else do they wish for but lengthened infirmity?
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let your old age be childlike, and your childhood like old age; that is, so that neither may your wisdom be with pride, nor your humility without wisdom.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Our prayers become effective through almsgiving; life is redeemed from dangers by almsgiving; souls are delivered from death by almsgiving.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The bread you store up belongs to the hungry; the cloak that lies in your chest belongs to the naked; the gold you have hidden in the ground belongs to the poor.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Scatter what you have, then, so that you may not lose; give away, so that you may keep; lay out, so that you may save; spend, so that you may gain. If your treasures are to be hoarded, don’t be the one who hoards them, for in doing so you will surely be throwing them away. Instead, entrust them to God, for no one can steal them from Him. … Lend to Him who gives an interest greater than the principal.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The rich man who gives to the poor does not bestow alms but pays a debt.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If we can enter the church day and night and implore God to hear our prayers, how careful we should be to hear and grant the petitions of our neighbors in need.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We must be charitable and humble and give alms, because they wash the stains of sin from our souls.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It would be considered a theft on our part if we didn’t give to someone in greater need than we are.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We must give alms. Charity wins souls and draws them to virtue.
author: Angela Merici
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The only true riches are those that make us rich in virtue. Therefore, if you want to be rich, beloved, love true riches. If you aspire to the heights of real honor, strive to reach the kingdom of heaven. If you value rank and renown, hasten to be enrolled in the heavenly court of the angels.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Ambition is the mother of hypocrisy and prefers to skulk in corners and dark places. It cannot endure the light of day. It is an unclean vice wallowing in the depths, always hidden, but ever with an eye to advancement.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Saints The whole air about us is filled with angels.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Now it was not for the angels that Christ died. Yet what was done for the redemption of man through His death was in a sense done for the angels, because the enmity that sin had put between men and the holy angels is removed, and friendship is restored between them, and by the redemption of man the gaps that the great apostasy left in the angelic host are filled up.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: An angel is an intelligent being, ever in motion, with free will, incorporeal, ministering to God, having by grace obtained immortality in his nature, the form and limitation of whose essence is known to the Creator alone.
author: John of Damascus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If we saw an angel clearly, we would die of pleasure.
author: Bridget of Sweden
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Since God often sends us inspirations by means of His angels, we should frequently return our aspirations to Him by means of the same messengers.
author: Frances de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Make yourself familiar with the angels, and behold them frequently in spirit. Without being seen, they are present with you.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Every breath of air and ray of light and heat, every beautiful prospect, is, as it were, the skirts of their garments, the waving of the robes of those whose faces see God in heaven.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Our weakness is such that, if the guardian angels had not been given to us, we could not resist the many and powerful attacks of the evil spirits. For this purpose, we had need of a higher nature. … That is why God has taken these spirits out from among His treasures, and has given through them an aid to human weakness, so that this divine assistance might help us against the powers of this world of darkness to attain the heritage of salvation.
author: Hilary of Poitiers
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Beside each believer stands an angel as protector and shepherd, leading him to life.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: An angel is put in charge of every believer, provided we do not drive him out by sin. He guards the soul like an army.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We pray to the angels, for they are given to us as guardians.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: So valuable to heaven is the dignity of the human soul that every member of the human race has a guardian angel from the moment the person begins to be. Jerome Our deeds are daily, both day and night, reported to the Lord by the angels assigned to us.
author: Benedict of Nursia
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: They are the guardians of the divisions of the earth; they are set over nations and regions allotted to them by their Creator. They govern all our affairs and bring us help. And the reason surely is that they are set over us by the divine will and command and are ever in the vicinity of God.
author: John of Damascus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The world of pure spirits stretches between the Divine Nature and the world of men. Because Divine Wisdom has ordained that the higher should look after the lower, angels execute the divine plan for human salvation: They are our guardians, who free us when hindered and help to bring us home.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If you find it impossible to pray, hide behind your good angel and charge him to pray in your stead.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When tempted, invoke your angel. He is more eager to help you than you are to be helped! Ignore the devil and do not be afraid of him: He trembles and flees at the sight of your guardian angel.
author: John Bosco
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I tell you truly, my beloved, that our carelessness and our humiliation and our turning aside from the way are not a loss to us only, but they are a weariness for the angels and for all the saints in Jesus Christ. Our humiliation gives grief to them all, and our salvation gives joy and refreshment to them all.
author: Antony the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I bind to myself today the power in the love of the Seraphim, in the obedience of the Angels, in the ministration of the Archangels, in the hope of Resurrection unto reward, in the prayers of the Patriarchs, in the predictions of the Prophets, in the preaching of the Apostles, in the faith of the Confessors, in the purity of the holy Virgins, in the deeds of Righteous men.
author: Patrick of Ireland
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: So great was my joy in God that I took no heed of looking at the angels and the saints, because all their goodness and all their beauty was from Him and in Him; He was the whole and supreme Good, with all beauty, and so great a joy had I in His words that I paid no heed to any creature.
author: Angela of Foligno
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I call upon the angels and saints, who fly like eagles straight toward their fiery goal; their protection will defend me against the birds of prey that threaten to devour me. The spirits of evil cannot claim me for their own; I belong only to You, Jesus, You who have Your nest up there in the sun of love. Thérèse of Lisieux It is blasphemy if you pray before God while you are full of wrath.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Anger is a kind of temporary madness.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If an angry man raises the dead, God is still displeased with his anger.
author: Abba Agatho
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Guard your tongue when your husband is angry. Monica Imagine your anger to be a kind of wild beast … because it too has ferocious teeth and claws, and if you don’t tame it, it will devastate all things. … It not only hurts the body; it even corrupts the health of the soul, devouring, rending, tearing to pieces all its strength, and making it useless for everything.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: What is hatred, after all, than anger that was allowed to remain, that has become ingrained and deep-rooted? What was anger when it was fresh becomes hatred when it is aged.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: As long as anger lives, she continues to be the fruitful mother of many unhappy children.
author: John Climacus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There is no sin nor wrong that gives a man such a foretaste of hell in this life as anger and impatience.
author: Catherine of Siena
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: You will accomplish more by kind words and a courteous manner than by anger or sharp rebuke, which should never be used except in necessity.
author: Angela Merici
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: This deadly cancer of anger from which so much harm grows: It makes us unlike ourselves, makes us like timber wolves or furies from hell, drives us forth headlong upon the points of swords, makes us blindly run forth after other men’s destruction as we hasten toward our own ruin.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: From what does such contrariness arise in habitually angry people, but from a secret cause of too high an opinion of themselves so that it pierces their heart when they see any man esteem them less than they esteem themselves?. … An inflated estimation of ourselves is more than half the weight of our wrath.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If we should see two men fighting together over serious matters, we would still think them both crazy if they did not leave off fighting when they saw a ferocious lion coming toward them, ready to devour them both. Now considering that we surely see that death is coming on us all, and will undoubtedly within a short time devour us all—how soon, we don’t know— isn’t it worse than insanity to be angry and bear malice to one another, more often than not over trivial matters, in the same way children fight over cherry stones?
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Dismiss all anger and look into yourself a little. Remember that he of whom you are speaking is your brother and, as he is in the way of salvation, God can make him a saint, in spite of his present weakness.
author: Thomas of Villanova
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Why lose your temper if by doing so you offend God, annoy other people, give yourself a bad time … and in the end have to find it again?
author: Josemaria Escriva
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Reason opposes evil all the more effectively when anger resides at her side.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There is a holy anger, excited by zeal, that moves us to reprove with warmth those whom our mildness foiled to correct.
author: Jean Baptiste de la Salle
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Whatever has been prophesied is coming to pass, and as the end of the world approaches, it tests both men and the times.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If the walls of your home were shaking with age, the roofs above you were trembling, and the house, now worn out and wearied, were threatening an immediate collapse of a structure crumbling with age, wouldn’t you get out of it as quickly as possible? If you were on a voyage, and an angry, raging tempest violently aroused by the waves foretold the coming shipwreck, wouldn’t you quickly seek harbor? Well, the world is changing and passing away; it witnesses to its own ruin now, not by old age, but by the end of things. So shouldn’t you thank God, shouldn’t you congratulate yourself, if by an early departure you’re taken away and rescued from the shipwrecks and disasters that are imminent?
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Elijah … will come; the Jews will believe; Antichrist will persecute; Christ will judge; the dead will rise; the good and the wicked will be separated; the world will be burned and renewed. All these things, we believe, will come to pass; but how, or in what order, human understanding cannot perfectly teach us—we will know only when we have experienced the events themselves.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In vain, then, do we attempt to compute definitely the years that may remain to this world, when we may hear from the mouth of the Truth Himself that it is not for us to know this.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: While the hot restlessness of heretics stirs questions about many articles of the Catholic faith, the necessity of defending them forces us to investigate them more accurately, to understand them more clearly, and to proclaim them more earnestly; and the question mooted by an adversary becomes the occasion of instruction.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: My object is … to have the naked truth made known to all who are astray and to have it revealed by God’s help through my ministry, commending itself so well that they may embrace and follow it.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Heretics are to be converted by an example of humility and other virtues for more readily than by any external display or verbal battles. So let us arm ourselves with devout prayers and set off showing signs of genuine humility and go barefooted to combat Goliath. Dominic Nothing is so difficult as to enter into the characters and feelings of men who have been brought up under a system of religion different from our own; and to discern how they may be most forcibly and profitably addressed, in order to win them over to the reception of divine truths, of which they are at present ignorant.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: My spirit has become dry because it forgets to feed on You.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: As to the aridity you are suffering from, it seems to me our Lord is treating you like someone He considers strong: He wants to test you and see if you love Him as much at times of aridity as when He sends you consolations. I think this is a very great favor for God to show you.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t let aridity distress you: Perfection has nothing to do with such things —only with virtues. Your devotion will come back when you are least expecting it.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: One single act done with aridity of spirit is worth more than many done with feelings of devotion.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A work of art represents the mind of the maker.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is right to submit to a higher authority whenever a command of God would not be violated.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When we offend those set over us, we oppose the ordinance of Him who set them above us.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Men desire authority for its own sake that they may bear a rule, command and control other men, and live uncommanded and uncontrolled themselves.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To know whom to avoid is a great means of saving our souls.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Nothing can be more dangerous than keeping wicked companions. They communicate the infection of their vices to all who associate with them.
author: Jean Baptiste de la Salle If
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I had to advise parents, I should tell them to take great care about the people with whom their children associate. … Much harm may result from bad company, and we are inclined by nature to follow what is worse rather than what is better.
author: Elizabeth Ann Seton
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Glory be to Him who was baptized, and thus drowned our iniquity in the deep, and suffocated the one who had suffocated us!
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Mighty is the water in the seas, yet it is too weak for atonement; the water of baptism alone is able to atone.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Today your offenses are blotted out and your names are written down. The priest blots out in the water, and Christ writes down in heaven.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: You who are baptized: Conquer the darkness by the light of your candles, and the silence by your hosannas!
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The fountain of baptism is set to protect against the flame. This is the water that avails for the quenching of hell.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The diver brings up the pearl out of the sea. Be baptized and bring up from the water the purity that is hidden there, the pearl that is set like a jewel in the crown of the Godhead.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The seaman stores up sweet water in his vessel; in the midst of the sea he lays up and keeps it, the sweet in the midst of the bitter. In the same way, amidst the floods of sin, keep the water of baptism.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Baptism is ransom, forgiveness of debts, death of sin, regeneration of the soul, a resplendent garment, an unbreakable seal, a chariot to heaven, a royal protector, a gift of adoption.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Lord was baptized, not to be cleansed Himself, but to cleanse the waters, so that those waters, cleansed by the flesh of Christ which knew no sin, might have the power of baptism.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: For the spirit of man is sanctified by the Spirit, when the body has been sanctified by water. For just as water, when it is poured into cauldrons and set over a blazing fire, draws power from the fire, so too by the means of the operation of the Spirit the tangible water is transformed into some divine and indescribable power, and it sanctifies those in whom it would work rebirth.
author: Cyril of Alexandria
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Just as a man cannot live in the flesh unless he is born in the flesh, even so a man cannot have the spiritual life of grace unless he is born again spiritually. This regeneration is effected by baptism: “Unless a man is born again of water and the Holy Spirit, he cannot enter into the kingdom of God” [Jn 3:5].
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Christ has made my soul beautiful with the jewels of grace and virtue. I belong to Him whom the angels serve. Agnes Beauty is indeed a good gift of God; but that the good may not think it a great good, God dispenses it even to the wicked.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Understanding is the reward of faith. Therefore, don’t seek to understand so that you may believe, but believe so that you may understand.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A person can do other things against his will, but belief is possible only in one who is willing.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We can’t have full knowledge all at once. We must start by believing; then afterwards we may be led on to master the evidence for ourselves.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When someone said to him, “I don’t believe in God,” he smiled and replied: But God believes in you!
author: Padre Pio of Pietrelcina
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Your presbytery … is as closely tied to the bishop as the strings to a harp. So your accord and harmonious love is a hymn to Jesus Christ. Yes, one and all, you should form yourselves into a choir, so that, in perfect harmony and taking your pitch from God, you may sing in unison and with one voice to the Father through Jesus Christ.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Everyone the Master of the house sends on His business, we ought to receive as the One who sent him. It is clear, then, that we should regard the bishop as the Lord Himself.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The episcopate is one, each part of which is held by each one for the whole.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Be obedient to your bishop and welcome him as the parent of your soul. Jerome The episcopate is the title of a work, not of an honor. … He who loves to rule his flock and not be useful to his flock is no bishop.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Poverty is the true characteristic of a bishop.
author: Alphonsus Liguori
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If a man cannot bear being reviled, he will not see glory. If he is not cleansed of bitterness, he will not savor sweetness. Barsanuphius The recollection of an injury is … a rusty arrow and poison for the soul.
author: Francis of Paola
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God is more anxious to bestow His blessings on us than we are to receive them.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is not God’s way that great blessings should descend without the sacrifice first of great sufferings.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let no one tell you that this body of ours is a stranger to God.
author: Cyril of Jerusalem
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t tell me that the body is the cause of sin: After all, if the body is the cause of sin, how is it that a corpse doesn’t sin? Put a sword in the right hand of someone who has just died, and no murder takes place. Let beautiful women of all kinds parade before a young man who has just died, and no lewd desire arises. Why not? Because the body of itself doesn’t sin —rather, the soul sins through the body. The body is the soul’s instrument, its cloak and garment.
author: Cyril of Jerusalem
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Our body is like armor, our soul like the warrior. Take care of both, and you will be ready for what comes.
author: Amma Syncletica
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The soul is the user, the body for use; hence the one is master, the other servant.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God is the Creator of the human body as well as the soul. Neither of these is evil, nor does God hate either of them: for He hates none of the things that He has made.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In no part of the human body visible to us is beauty sacrificed to utility, while there are some parts that serve no purpose except beauty. So I think we can readily conclude that when God created the body, He showed a greater regard for beauty than for necessity.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t ask me to give in to this body of mine. I can’t afford it. Between me and my body there must be a struggle until death.
author: Margaret of Cortona
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I have made a contract with my body: It has promised to accept harsh treatment from me on earth, and I have promised that it shall receive eternal rest in heaven.
author: Peter of Alcantara
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: One should never deny the body what is due to it, so that the body itself may not hinder what is due to the soul.
author: Peter of Alcantara
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In answer to a philosopher who asked him how he could be happy without books: My book, O philosopher, is the nature of created things, and any time I want to read the words of God, the book is before me.
author: Antony the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Never read books you aren’t sure about … even supposing that these bad books are very well written from a literary point of view. Let me ask you this: Would you drink something you knew was poisoned just because it was offered to you in a golden cup?
author: John Bosco
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Nothing is more common in an age like this, when books abound, than to fancy that the gratification of a love of reading is real study.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is our duty to live among books; especially to live by one Book, and a very old one.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I have my room, some books, and a nearby chapel. That is complete happiness.
author: Miguel of Ecuador
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The task of the catechist is to take up one or other of the truths of faith or of Christian morality, and then explain it in all its parts; and since amendment of life is the chief aim of his instruction, the catechist must needs make a comparison between what God commands us to do and what is our actual conduct. After this, he will use examples appropriately taken from the Holy Scriptures, Church history, and the lives of the saints—thus moving his hearers and clearly pointing out to them how they are to regulate their own conduct.
author: Pope Pius
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: X Christian is my name, and Catholic my surname. The one designates me, while the other manifests me for what I am. Thus am I attested and set apart. … When we are called Catholics, it is by this name that our people are kept apart from any heretical name.
author: Pacianus of Barcelona
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He is a true and genuine Catholic who loves the truth of God, the Church, and the Body of Christ; who puts nothing else before divine religion and the Catholic faith, neither the authority nor the love nor the genius nor the eloquence nor the philosophy of any man whatsoever; but, despising all that and being fixed, stable, and persevering in his faith, is determined in himself to hold and believe that only which he knows the Catholic Church has held universally and from ancient times.
author: Vincent of Lerins
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He cannot be accounted a Catholic who does not agree with the Roman Church.
author: Pope Gregory VII
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: No one can be a Catholic without a simple faith that what the Church declares in God’s name is God’s word, and therefore true. A man must simply believe that the Church is the oracle of God; he must be as certain of her mission as he is of the mission of the Apostles.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Catholicism is a deep matter, you cannot take it up in a tea-cup.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In the long run it will be found that either the Catholic religion is verily and indeed the coming in of the unseen world into this, or that there is nothing positive, nothing dogmatic, nothing real in any of our notions as to whence we come and whither we are going.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let nothing disturb you, nothing frighten you; all things are passing; God never changes.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Well and good if all things change, Lord God, provided we are rooted in You.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In a higher world it is otherwise; but here below, to live is to change, and to be perfect is to have changed often.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He who has charity is far from all sin.
author: Polycarp of Smyrna
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Charity is the bond of brotherhood, the foundation of peace, the mainstay and security of unity, which is greater than both hope and faith, which excels both good works and martyrdom, which will abide with us always, eternal with God in the kingdom of heaven.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I define charity as a motion of the soul whose purpose is to enjoy God for His own sake and oneself and one’s neighbor for the sake of God.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Charity is the form, mover, mother, and root of all the virtues.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It can only be disgraceful for some Christians to snore while other Christians are in peril.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Charity is that with which no one is lost, and without which no one is saved.
author: Robert Cardinal Bellarmine
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The school of Christ is the school of charity. On the last day, when the general examination takes place, there will be no question at all on the text of Aristotle, the aphorisms of Hippocrates, or the paragraphs of Justinian. Charity will be the whole syllabus.
author: Robert Cardinal Bellarmine
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: True virtue has no limits, but goes on and on, and especially holy charity, which is the virtue of virtues, and which, having an infinite object, would become infinite if it could meet with a heart capable of infinity.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t say that you have a chaste mind if you have unchaste eyes, because an unchaste eye is the messenger of an unchaste heart.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A prayer of his youth while he was still resisting God: Give me chastity and continence—but not yet.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Cheerfulness prepares a glorious mind for all the noblest acts of religion— love, adoration, praise, and every union with our God, as also for duties, charity, happy zeal, useful concern for our neighbor, and all those acts of piety which should improve cheerfulness, and dispose the poor soul to joyful serenity—resting all upon infinite goodness!
author: Elizabeth Ann Seton
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Better to instruct a child than to collect riches.
author: Herve of Brittany
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Both the raven and the ape think their own young the fairest.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Children should never be taken to church in dress that would not be thought good enough for appearing before company.
author: Jean Baptiste de la Salle
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I imagine that the angels themselves, if they came down as schoolmasters, would find it hard to control their anger. Only with the help of the Blessed Virgin do I keep from murdering some of them. Benildus You can do nothing with children unless you win their confidence and love by bringing them into touch with yourself, by breaking through all the hindrances that keep them at a distance. We must accommodate ourselves to their tastes, we must make ourselves like them.
author: John Bosco
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A child is a pledge of immortality, for he bears upon him in figure those high and eternal excellences in which the joy of heaven consists, and which would not thus be shadowed forth by the all-gracious Creator, were they not one day to be realized.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman My
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Lord, if it is necessary to give them a whipping or two to convert them, please do it, as long as their souls are saved in the end.
author: Padre Pio of Pietrelcina
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Jesus Christ, our Salvation, the High Priest of our offerings, the Protector and Helper of our weakness. Through Him we fix our gaze on the heights of heaven. In Him we see mirrored God’s pure and transcendent Face.
author: Pope Clement
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I Blessed be the Fruit, who lowered Himself to our famished state!
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When we speak about wisdom, we are speaking of Christ. When we speak about virtue, we are speaking of Christ. When we speak about justice, we are speaking of Christ. When we speak about peace, we are speaking of Christ. When we speak about truth and life and redemption, we are speaking of Christ.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Christ with me, Christ before me, Christ behind me, Christ within me, Christ below me, Christ above me, Christ at my right, Christ at my left, Christ in lying down, Christ in sitting, Christ in rising up, Christ in the heart of every man who thinks of me, Christ in the mouth of every man who speaks to me, Christ in every eye that sees me, Christ in every ear that hears me.
author: Patrick of Ireland
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Creator and Lord of all so loved the world, that He sent His Son for its salvation, the Prince and Savior of the faithful, who washed and dried our wounds, and from Him also came that most sweet medicine, from which all the good things of salvation flow.
author: Hildegard of Bingen
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If, then, you are looking for the way by which you should go, take Christ, because He Himself is the way.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He belongs to you, but more than that, He longs to be in you, living and ruling in you, as the head lives and rules in the body. He wants His breath to be in your breath, His heart in your heart, and His soul in your soul.
author: John Eudes
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Where they see the Blood of the Lord, demons flee while angels gather.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: This Blood, poured out in abundance, has washed the whole world clean.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Those who share in this Blood have taken their stand with angels, and archangels, and the powers from on high, clad in the royal uniform of Christ with spiritual weapons in their hands. Yet greater still than that: They are wearing the King Himself!
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: This is the price of the world; by it, Christ purchased the Church; by it, He adorned her entirely. Just as a man in buying slaves pays for them in gold and then, if he desires to beautify them, ornaments them with gold as well, so also Christ has both purchased us with His Blood and adorned us with His Blood.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Blood that but one drop of has the power to win All the world forgiveness of its world of sin.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Christ has no body on earth but yours, no hands but yours, no feet but yours. Yours are the eyes through which Christ’s compassion for the world is to look out; yours are the feet with which He is to go about doing good; and yours are the hands with which He is to bless us now.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: His face endured spitting, so that you might not shrink from scorn. … Endure scorn from your brother, so that you may be the companion of Christ.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Death’s pallid hue comes o’er You; the glow of life decays; Yet angel hosts adore You, and tremble as they gaze.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: What language shall I borrow to thank Thee, dearest Friend, For this, Thy dying sorrow, Thy pity without end? O make me Thine forever, and should I feinting be, Lord, let me never, never outlive my love for Thee!
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: You should carry the passion of God in your hearts, for it is man’s consolation in his last hour.
author: Nicholas of Flue
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Church has always taught that all our penance without Christ’s passion is not worth a pea.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Here learn the science of the saints: All is to be found in the passion of Jesus. Make every effort to remain hidden in the wounds of Jesus, and you will be enriched with every good and every true light, enabling you to fly to that Perfection which is consonant with your way of life.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The passion of Jesus is a sea of sorrows, but it is also an ocean of love. Ask the Lord to teach you to fish in this ocean. Dive into its depths. No matter how deep you go, you will never reach the bottom.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Make a little bouquet of the sufferings of Jesus and carry them in the bosom of the soul.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Mount Calvary is the academy of love.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I bind to myself today The might of the Incarnation of Christ with that of His Baptism, The might of His Crucifixion with that of His Burial, The might of His Resurrection with that of His Ascension, The might of His Coming on the Judgment Day.
author: Patrick of Ireland
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Blessed be the Babe who made manhood young again today!
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: How astonished I am that there is laid before me a Child who is older than all things!
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Child, the Lord Jesus Christ … Word in our flesh, Wisdom in infancy, Power in weakness, and in true Man, the Lord of Majesty.
author: Pope Leo the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: May He make us children of God, He who for our sakes wished to become a Child of man.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Christianity is an imitation of God’s nature.
author: Gregory of Nyssa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Imagine that a professional painter is commissioned to paint a portrait of the king for those who live far away. What if he draws an ugly caricature on the wood and calls this ungracious picture an image of the king? Wouldn’t it be likely that the authorities would be annoyed because the handsome original had been insulted through this bad portrait as it was viewed among those who had never seen the king? In a similar way, then, if … Christianity is an imitation of God, the person who has never been given an explanation of this mystery will assume that God is like us Christians.
author: Gregory of Nyssa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Since He is the Sun of Justice, He fittingly calls His disciples the light of the world. For through them, as through shining rays, He has poured out the light of the knowledge of Himself upon the entire world. For by manifesting the light of truth, they have dispelled the darkness of error from the hearts of men.
author: Chromatius of Aquileia
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In the lives of Christians we look not to the beginnings but to the endings. Jerome To be a Christian is the great thing, not merely to seem one. And somehow or other those please the world most who please Christ least. Jerome A true Christian may almost be defined as one who has a ruling sense of God’s presence within him.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: All days from the treasure of this bright day gain blessings. All the feasts from the stores of this feast have their fairness and their ornaments. … Great is this day above all days, for in it came forth mercy to sinners. A medicine chest is this Your great day, because on it shone forth the Medicine of life to the wounded. A treasure of helpful graces is this day, because on it, Light gleamed forth on our blindness. Yes, it also brought a Sheaf to us, and it came, so that from it, plenty might flow upon our hunger.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In this night of reconciliation, let none be angry or gloomy. In this night that stills everything, let nothing threaten or disturb. This night belongs to the sweet One; let nothing bitter or harsh be in it. In this night that belongs to the meek One, let there be nothing high or haughty. In this day of pardoning, let us not exact punishments for trespasses. In this day of gladness, let us not spread sadness. … In this day when God came to sinners, let not the righteous man be in his own mind uplifted over the sinner.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In this day in which the Rich became poor for our sakes, let the rich man make the poor man share with him at his table. On this day came forth to us the Gift, even though we had not asked for it! Let us therefore bestow alms on those who cry and beg from us.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Today Godhead pressed itself like a seal upon manhood, so that with the Godhead’s stamp, manhood might be adorned.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Christ is born, so that by His birth He might restore your nature.
author: Peter Chrysologus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Celebrate the feast of Christmas every day, even every moment in the interior temple of your spirit, remaining like a baby in the bosom of the heavenly Father, where you will be reborn each moment in the Divine Word, Jesus Christ.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Permanence of the Catholic; Church, the Unity of the Catholic Where the bishop is, there let the people gather, just as where Jesus Christ is, there is the Catholic Church.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Where the Church is, there is the Spirit of God; and where the Spirit of God is, there is the Church and all grace—and the Spirit is truth.
author: Irenaeus of Lyons
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We should not seek from others for the truth that can easily be received from the Church. There the apostles, like a rich man making a deposit, fully bestowed upon her all that belongs to the truth, so that whoever wishes may receive from her the water of life.
author: Irenaeus of Lyons
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: She is the entrance to life; all the others are thieves and robbers.
author: Irenaeus of Lyons
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The very tradition, teaching, and faith of the Catholic Church from the beginning, which the Lord gave, was preached by the apostles and was preserved by the Fathers. On this was the Church founded, and if anyone departs from this, he neither is, nor any longer ought to be called, a Christian.
author: Athanasius of Alexandria
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: You cannot have God for your Father if you don’t have the Church for your mother.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: From her womb we are born, by her milk we are nourished, by her Spirit we are made alive.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is the peculiar property of the Church that when she is buffeted, she is triumphant; when she is assaulted with argument she proves herself in the right; when she is deserted by her supporters, she holds the field.
author: Hilary of Poitiers
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He who sees the Church looks directly at Christ—Christ building and increasing by the addition of the elect.
author: Gregory of Nyssa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The establishment of the Church is a re-creation of the world.
author: Gregory of Nyssa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Christ and the Church are two in one flesh.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Your mother is the Church, and her breasts are the two Testaments of the divine Scriptures. Suckle them to drink the milk of all the sacraments.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Catholic Church is the work of divine Providence, achieved through the prophecies of the prophets, through the Incarnation and the teaching of Christ, through the journeys of the apostles, through the suffering, the crosses, the blood and death of the martyrs, through the admirable lives of the saints. … When we see, then, so much help on God’s part, so much progress and so much fruit, shall we hesitate to bury ourselves in the bosom of that Church? For beginning with the apostolic chair, down through successions of bishops, even to the open confession of all mankind, it has possessed the crown of teaching authority.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Anyone who is outside this Church, which received the keys of the kingdom of heaven, is walking a path not to heaven but to hell. … Let them hasten, then, while there is yet time, to their legitimate Mother, who legitimately sustains and nourishes the sons born of her womb.
author: Fulgence of Ruspe
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The teaching of the Church … is both the starting line and the finish line for the race; it is the bridle of a tightly reined horse.
author: John of Damascus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Church is like a great ship being pounded by the waves of life’s different stresses. Our duty is not to abandon ship, but to keep her on her course.
author: Boniface of Mainz
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There is but one Church in which men find salvation, just as outside the ark of Noah it was not possible for anyone to be saved.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Just as in one man there is one soul and one body, yet many members; even so the Catholic Church is one body, having many members. The soul that quickens this body is the Holy Spirit; and therefore in the Creed after confessing our belief in the Holy Spirit, we are bid to believe in the Holy Catholic Church.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To Pope Gregory XI: Since the Church began aiming more at temporal things than at spiritual, things have gone from bad to worse.
author: Catherine of Siena
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Comfort in tribulation can be secured only on the sure ground of faith holding as true the words of Scripture and the teaching of the Catholic Church.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Either Christ has a Church in the world continually and until the end of the world, or else He has a Church sometimes, and sometimes not at all. Could we think that He had a Church while He was here Himself, and perhaps awhile after, but—mysteriously—none since? … No … that can in no way be, since He must necessarily still preserve His Church somewhere; otherwise, how could He be with His followers continually until the end of the world?
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If we wish to proceed securely in all things, we must hold fast to the following principle: What seems to me white, I will believe black if the hierarchical Church so defines. For I must be convinced that in Christ our Lord, the Bridegroom, and in His spouse the Church, only one Spirit holds sway, who governs and rules for the salvation of souls. For it is by the same Spirit and Lord who gave the Ten Commandments that our Holy Mother Church is ruled and governed.
author: Ignatius Loyola
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Holy Church—that Mother who is also a Queen because she is a King’s bride. Thérèse of Lisieux Divine assistance for the Church is not restricted to the first centuries of the Church, but is continued and will be continued to the end of time. This reflection has calmed my spirit on more than one occasion. May it serve to calm yours when you witness error worming its way about.
author: Dominic Barberi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I will go peaceably and firmly to the Catholic Church: for if Faith is so important to our salvation, I will seek it where true Faith first began, seek it among those who received it from God Himself.
author: Elizabeth Ann Seton
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There are but two ways, the way to Rome and the way to atheism.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: This is holy Church, the one Church, the true Church, the Catholic Church, fighting against all heresies; she can fight, but she cannot be conquered. All heresies are expelled from her as if they were dead branches pruned from the vine; she herself, however, remains fixed in her root, in her vine, in her charity. The gates of hell shall not prevail against her.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Church has ever proved indestructible. Her persecutors have failed to destroy her; in fact, it was during times of persecution that the Church grew more and more; while the persecutors themselves, and those whom the Church would destroy, are the very ones who came to nothing. … Again, errors have assailed her; but in fact, the greater the number of errors that have arisen, the more has the truth been made manifest. … Nor has the Church failed before the assaults of demons: for she is like a tower of refuge to all who fight against the Devil.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When [Christianity] dies, at least the world will die with it. The world’s duration is measured by it. If the Church dies, the world’s time is run. The world shall never exult over the [demise of the] Church. If the Church falls sick, the world shall utter a wail for its own sake; for, like Samson, the Church will bury all with it.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

topic: CHURCH, THE UNITY OF THE CATHOLIC—
quote: See also Church, the Catholic God is One and Christ is One, and one is His Church, and the faith is one, and His people welded together by the glue of concord into a solid unity of body. Unity cannot be rent asunder; nor can the one body of the Church, through the division of its structure, be divided into separate pieces.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

topic: CHURCH, THE UNITY OF THE CATHOLIC—
quote: His Church is one, His see is one, founded by the voice of the Lord on Peter. No other altar can be set up, no other priesthood instituted apart from that one altar and that one priesthood. Whoever gathers elsewhere, scatters.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

topic: CHURCH, THE UNITY OF THE CATHOLIC—
quote: In the Scriptures our people are shown to be made one; so that just as many grains collected into one and ground and mingled together make one loaf, so in Christ, who is the heavenly Bread, we know there is one body, in which our whole company is joined and united.
author: Hilary of Poitiers
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

topic: CHURCH, THE UNITY OF THE CATHOLIC—
quote: Hold firmly that our faith is identical with that of the ancients. Deny this, and you dissolve the unity of the Church.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If it is “daily bread,” why do you take it once a year? … Take daily what is to profit you daily. Live in such a way that you may deserve to receive it daily. He who does not deserve to receive it daily, does not deserve to receive it once a year.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We can afford to lose castles, but we cannot let a day go by without attending holy Mass.
author: Charles of Blois
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If someone knows from experience that daily Communion increases fervor without lessening reverence, then let him go every day. But if someone finds that reverence is lessened and devotion not much increased, then let him sometimes abstain, so as to draw near afterwards with better dispositions.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There is neither past nor present nor future for Jesus Christ. This good Father knew us all at the Last Supper. He consecrated, as it were in thought and in desire, all our Hosts; He loved us personally … centuries before we were born. Yes, we were present at the Last Supper, and Jesus stored up for us not one Host but a hundred, a thousand, one for every day of our life. … Our Hosts are ready; let us not lose a single one of them.
author: Peter Julian Eymard
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Keep up your daily Communion and think: What would I be if I had not gone?
author: Josemaria Escriva
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If the apostles and martyrs while still in the body can pray for others, at a time when they should still be solicitous about themselves, how much more will they do so after their crowns, victories, and triumphs? Jerome What do they not see, who see Him who sees all things?
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Just as in a physical body the operation of one member contributes to the good of the whole body, so it is in a spiritual body such as the Church. And since all the faithful are one body, the good of one member is communicated to another; every one members, as the Apostle says, of one another [Eph 4:25]. For that reason, among the points of faith handed down by the Apostles, is that there is a community of goods in the Church, and this is expressed in the words communion of saints.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The greater the charity of the saints in their heavenly home, the more they intercede for those who are still on their journey and the more they can help them by their prayers; the more they are united with God, the more effective those prayers are. This is in accordance with divine order, which makes higher things react upon lower things, like the brightness of the sun filling the atmosphere.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
