source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Those in the Catholic Church, whom some rebuke for praying to saints and going on pilgrimages, do not seek any saint as their savior. Instead, they seek saints as those whom their Savior loves, and whose intercession and prayer for the seeker He will be content to hear. For His own sake, He would have those He loves honored. And when they are thus honored for His sake, then the honor that is given them for His sake overflows especially to Himself.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Considering that when the saints lived in this world they were at liberty to roam the earth, do you really think that in heaven God would have them tied to a post?
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: You say you see no reason why we should pray to the saints since God can hear us and help us just as well, and will do so gladly, as any saint in heaven. Well, then, what need, I ask, do you have to ask any physician to help your fever, or to ask and pay any surgeon to heal your sore leg? For God can both hear you and help you as well as the best of doctors, He loves you more than they do, and He can help you sooner. Besides—His poultices are cheaper and He will give you more for your words alone than they will for your money!
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If Saint Paul exhorts us to pray for one another, and we gladly think it right to ask every poor man to pray for us, should we think it evil to ask the holy saints in heaven to do the same?
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Do you think, daughters, that God comes to you all by Himself? … You may be sure that such a King is not left alone by the attendants of His court; but they attend Him, praying to Him for us, and for our welfare, because they are full of love.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I shall be able to do much more for you in heaven than I can now while I am on earth.
author: Padre Pio of Pietrelcina
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Confession puts out the fires of hell for you.
author: Pacianus of Barcelona
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Have you sinned? Go into church and wipe out your sin. As often as you might fall down in the marketplace, you pick yourself up again. So too, as often as you sin, repent your sin. Do not despair.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If the serpent, the Devil, bites someone secretly, he infects that person with the venom of sin. And if the one who was bitten keeps silence and does not do penance, and does not want to confess his wound to his brother and to his Master, then his brother and his Master, who have the word that will cure him, cannot very well assist him. For if the sick man is ashamed to confess his wound to the physician, medicine will not cure that to which it is not applied. Jerome If you want to flee from God, flee to Him instead. Flee to Him by confessing to Him; don’t flee from Him by trying to hide. For you can’t hide, but you can confess.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In failing to confess, Lord, I would only hide You from myself, not myself from You.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The demon which by your silence you let dwell in your heart has been killed because you confessed your sin. … Henceforth he shall never make a home in you, because you have thrown him out of doors into the open air. Theonas To do penance is to bewail the evil we have done, and to do no evil to bewail.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Confession heals, confession justifies, confession grants pardon of sin, all hope consists in confession; in confession there is a chance for mercy.
author: Isidore of Seville
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In the life of the body a man is sometimes sick, and unless he takes medicine, he will die. Even so in the spiritual life a man is sick on account of sin. For that reason he needs medicine so that he may be restored to health; and this grace is bestowed in the sacrament of Penance.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Three conditions are necessary for Penance: contrition, which is sorrow for sin, together with a purpose of amendment; confession of sins without any omission; and satisfaction by means of good works.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The minister to whom confession is made is the delegate of Christ, who is the Judge of the living and the dead.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Go to your confessor; open your heart to him; display to him all the recesses of your soul; take the advice that he will give you with the utmost humility and simplicity. For God, who has an infinite love for obedience, frequently renders profitable the counsels we take from others, but especially from those who are the guides of our souls.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: My children, when we have a little stain on our souls, we must do like someone who has a beautiful crystal globe of which she takes great care. If the globe gets a little dusty, when she sees it, she will pass a sponge over it, and there is the globe bright and shining again.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A person who is suffering from a slight illness … has no need to go and see a doctor; she can get well alone. … But if it is a serious illness, if it is a dangerous wound, then the doctor must be called in, and after the doctor come the medicines. When we have fallen into some grave sin, we must go to the doctor, who is the priest, and take the medicine, which is confession.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Our Lord Himself I saw in … this venerable Sacrament. … I felt as if my chains fell, as those of St. Peter at the touch of the divine messenger. My God, what new scenes for my soul!
author: Elizabeth Ann Seton
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Just as those who are born in the body need to be fortified so that the body may become operative, even so those who are reborn in the spirit need to be fortified by the Holy Spirit. For this reason, so that they might become strong, the apostles received the Holy Spirit after Christ’s ascension. … This power is conferred in the sacrament of Confirmation.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Those who have charge of children ought to be most careful to see that they be confirmed, because great grace is bestowed in Confirmation. Besides, one who is confirmed receives, when he dies, greater glory than one who has not been confirmed, because he has received more grace.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Look into the hiding places of your own conscience.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Conscience and reputation are two things. Conscience is due to yourself; reputation is due to your neighbor.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God’s law enters our mind and draws it to itself by stirring up conscience, which itself is called the law of our mind.
author: John of Damascus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The testimony of a man’s conscience is his only perfect and complete excuse.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A good conscience is a mine of wealth. And in truth what greater riches can there be, what thing more sweet, than a good conscience?
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Jesus Christ loves to rest in pure and tranquil consciences.
author: Henry Suso
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God desires from you the least degree of purity of conscience more than all the works you can perform.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: My conscience is my crown; contented thoughts my rest; My heart is happy in itself; my bliss is in my breast.
author: Robert Southwell
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Conscience has rights because it has duties.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Conscience is nearer to me than any other means of knowledge.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Perfection does not consist in consolation, but rather in the submission of the will to God alone; submission above all in things that are hard and bitter.
author: Henry Suso
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I call it consolation when an interior movement is stirred up in the soul, by which it is set on fire with love of its Creator and Lord, and as a consequence can love no creature on the face of the earth for its own sake, but only in the Creator of them all. It is likewise consolation when we shed tears that move us to love God, whether it is because of sorrow for sins, or because of the sufferings of Christ our Lord, or for any other reason that is immediately directed to the praise and service of God. Finally, I call consolation every increase of faith, hope, and charity, and all interior joy that invites and attracts us to what is heavenly and to the salvation of our soul by filling it with peace and quiet in its Creator and Lord.
author: Ignatius Loyola
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There are certain souls who are always looking for consolation in prayer; this is a delusion of the Devil, who simply wishes to bring about their destruction.
author: Alphonsus Liguori
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When you have no consolations, you serve God for Himself alone; but when you have them you’re liable to serve Him out of love for yourself.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The contemplation of God is promised to us as the goal of all our acts and the eternal consummation of all our joys.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The greatness of contemplation can be given to none but those who love.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The grace of contemplation is granted only in response to a longing and insistent desire.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When you have stabilized your heart in right faith, and steadfast hope, and perfect love, then you will heave up your heart in high contemplation of your Creator.
author: Edmund of Abingdon
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Better to illuminate than merely to shine, to deliver to others contemplated truths than merely to contemplate.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Contemplation is nothing else than a secret, peaceful, and loving infusion of God, which if admitted, will set the soul on fire with the Spirit of love.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Whoever wishes to hold the fortress of contemplation must first of all train in the camp of action.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We ascend to the heights of contemplation by the steps of action.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In the active life all the vices are first of all to be removed by the practice of good works, so that in the contemplative life a man may, with now purified mental gaze, pass on to the contemplation of the divine light.
author: Isidore of Seville
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There are in truth three states of the converted: the beginning, the middle, and the perfection. In the beginning they experience the charms of sweetness; in the middle the contests of temptation; and in the end the fullness of perfection.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Heaven is filled with converted sinners of all kinds, and there is room for more.
author: Joseph Cafasso
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: First let a little love find entrance into their hearts, and the rest will follow.
author: Philip Neri
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: You can win more converts with a spoonful of honey than with a barrelful of vinegar.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A convert is undeniably in favor with no party; he is looked at with distrust, contempt, and aversion by all. His former friends think him a good riddance, and his new friends are cold and strange; and as to the impartial public, their very first impression is to impute the change to some eccentricity of character, or fickleness of mind, or tender attachment, or private interest. Their utmost praise is the reluctant confession that “doubtless he is very sincere.”
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We must accept correction, beloved, and no one should resent it. The exhortations by which we admonish one another are both good and highly profitable, for they bind us to the will of God.
author: Pope Clement
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I Reprimand and rebuke should be accepted as healing remedies for vice and as conducive to good health. From this it is clear that those who pretend to be tolerant because they wish to flatter—those who thus fail to correct sinners—actually cause them to suffer supreme loss and plot the destruction of that life which is their true life.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Eating and drinking don’t make friendships—such friendship even robbers and murderers have. But if we are friends, if we truly care for one another, let’s help one another spiritually. … Let’s hinder those things that lead our friends away to hell.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t imagine that you love your children when you never discipline them, or that you love your neighbors when you never admonish them. This isn’t love, but mere weakness. Let your love be eager to correct, to reform.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Sometimes hatred is charming, while love must show itself severe.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The better friends you are, the straighter you can talk, but while you are only on nodding terms, be slow to scold.
author: Francis Xavier
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Never rebuke while you’re still indignant about a fault committed—wait until the next day, or even longer. Then calmly, and with a purer intention, make your reprimand. You’ll gain more by a friendly word than by a three- hour quarrel.
author: Josemaria Escriva
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The apostate angels taught us to paint the eyes with blackness drawn round them in a circle, and to stain the cheeks with a deceitful red, and to change the hair with false colors, and to mask all truth about the real appearance of face and head. … God says, “Let us make man in our image and likeness”; does anyone dare to alter and change what God has made? They are laying hands on God when they try to reform what He has formed.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Suppose an artist paints in beautiful lines and colors the likeness of someone’s face and form. Then, once the portrait is completed, someone else comes along, picks it up and, thinking that he could do a better job, makes changes in the picture. Wouldn’t that be a serious wrong to the first artist, and a good reason for him to be indignant? And do you think it likely you could get away with acting the same way, with a rash and wicked presumption that offends God—the Artist who created you?
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: By dyeing your hair the color of flame, you make it a terrible foreshadowing of the fiery judgment that awaits you!
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Fortitude is the disposition of soul that enables us to despise all inconveniences and the loss of things not in our power.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The principal act of courage is to endure and withstand dangers doggedly rather than to attack them.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Though the path is plain and smooth for men of good will, he who walks it will not travel far, and will do so only with difficulty, if he does not have good feet: that is, courage and a persevering spirit.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Courage! In the spiritual life, whoever doesn’t go forward goes backward. It’s the same as with a boat that must always go forward. If it stands still, the wind will blow it back.
author: Padre Pio of Pietrelcina
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Greed will demand of you labor, danger, hardships, and troubles, and you will readily agree to its demands. For what purpose? So you can have what will fill up your purse but empty out your peace of mind!
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is wrong for anyone to be anxious to receive more from his neighbor than he himself is willing to give to God.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Covetousness is like fire: the more wood that is fed to it, the more fervent and greedy it is.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The covetous claim to be Christian, yet they have no trust in Christ. For they are always afraid of want in the time to come, no matter how much they have.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: This covetous gathering and miserly keeping of wealth, with all the delight that we take in beholding it, is only a very gay and golden dream, in which we imagine we have great riches; and in the sleep of this life we are glad and proud of it. But when death has once awakened us, our dream shall vanish, and of all the treasure that we only dreamed about, we shall not find one penny left in our hand.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I have heard thousands of confessions, but never one of covetousness.
author: Francis Xavier
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Creation is a great book. Look above you; look below you! Note it; read it! God … didn’t write that book with ink. Instead, He set before your eyes the things that He had made. Can you ask for a louder voice than that? Why, heaven and earth cry out to you, “God made me!”
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Even the tiniest insect cannot be considered attentively without astonishment and without praising the Creator.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: All creatures have the same Source as we have. Like us, they derive the life of thought, love, and will from the Creator. Not to hurt our humble brethren is our first duty to them; but to stop there is a complete misapprehension of the intentions of Providence. We have a higher mission. God wishes that we should succor them whenever they require it.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If there is anyone who is not enlightened by this sublime magnificence of created things, he is blind. … If there is anyone who, seeing all these works of God, does not praise Him, he is dumb; if there is anyone who, from so many signs, cannot perceive God, that man is foolish. Bonaventure In everything, whether it is a thing sensed or a thing known, God Himself is hidden within. Bonaventure God passes through the thicket of the world, and wherever His glance falls He turns all things to beauty.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Listen to the sermon preached to you by the flowers, the trees, the shrubs, the sky, and the whole world. Notice how they preach to you a sermon full of love, of praise of God, and how they invite you to glorify the sublimity of that sovereign Artist who has given them being.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The other day … the little birds were singing in the woods. I began to weep. Poor little creatures, I thought within myself, the good God has made you to sing, and you sing. Yet man, who was created that he might love God, loves Him not!
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Know the Creed and the Our Father yourselves and teach them to your children. I do not know how a man can call himself a Christian … when he neglects to learn the few short lines of the Creed or the Our Father.
author: Caesarius of Arles
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Glory be to You, who laid your Cross as a bridge over death, that souls might pass over it from the dwelling of the dead to the dwelling of life!
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Faithful Cross, above all other, one and only noble tree … Sweet the wood, and sweet the iron, and thy load, most sweet is He.
author: Venantius Fortunatus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Through the Cross the nations were caught as in a net, and the seeds of faith were sown everywhere. With the Cross, as though with a plow, the disciples of Christ cultivated the unfruitful nature of mankind, revealed the Church’s ever-green pastures, and gathered in an abundant harvest of believers in Christ. By the Cross the martyrs were strengthened, and as they fell they smote down those who struck them. Through the Cross Christ became known, and the Church of the faithful, with the Scriptures ever open before her, introduces us to this same Christ, the Son of God, who is truly God and truly Lord.
author: Andrew of Crete
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Once as the tree of torture known—now the bright gate to Jesus’ throne.
author: Peter Damian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If you were the handsomest and the richest man in the world, and could work wonders and drive out devils, all that would be something extrinsic to you; it would not belong to you and you could not boast of it. But there is one thing of which we can boast; we can boast of our humiliations and in taking up daily the holy cross of our Lord Jesus Christ.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The law that is perfect because it takes away all imperfections is charity, and you find it written with a strange beauty when you gaze at Jesus your Savior stretched out like a sheet of parchment on the Cross, inscribed with wounds, illustrated in His own loving blood. Where else … is there a comparable book of love to read from?
author: Jordan of Saxony
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Cross possesses such power and strength that, whether they will or not, it attracts, draws, and ravishes those who carry it.
author: Henry Suso
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: However much we do to avoid them, we shall never lack crosses in this life if we are in the ranks of the Crucified.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Be proud that you are helping God to bear the Cross, and don’t grasp at comforts. It is only mercenaries who expect to be paid by the day. Serve Him without pay.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Whoever doesn’t seek the cross of Christ doesn’t seek the glory of Christ.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Cross is the way to paradise, but only when it is borne willingly.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In uniting yourself to God’s will, you take on new life and gather great courage, willingly embracing the cross and kissing His hand even when it chastises you, a hand that reaches out to you in love and has no other intention but your greater spiritual well-being.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Cross is the ladder to heaven.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: On the road to the Cross, it’s only the first few yards that hurt.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Put a good bunch of grapes under the winepress, and a delicious juice will come out. Under the winepress of the Cross, our soul produces a juice that feeds and strengthens us. When we haven’t got any crosses, we are dry: If we carry them with resignation, what happiness, what sweetness we feel!
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Contrarieties bring us to the foot of the Cross, and the Cross to the gate of heaven.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Crosses release us from this world, and by doing so, bind us to God.
author: Charles de Foucauld
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In charity, follow the deceased with sorrow and with offerings, and pray that he may have rest in the hidden place where he is going.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We have loved them during life; let us not abandon them until we have conducted them by our prayers into the house of the Lord.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The whole Church observes the custom handed down by our fathers: that those who have died within the fellowship of Christ’s body and blood should be prayed for when they are commemorated in their own place at the Holy Sacrifice, and that we should be reminded that this sacrifice is offered for them as well. When these acts of mercy are solemnly performed for their sake, who can doubt that we are truly giving them our support? The prayers we offer to God for them are not futile. We must not waver in our belief that they are profitable to the dead, to those of the dead at least who have lived in such a way before death that these things can be useful to them afterward.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: On the death of Pope St. Pius X: I believe that his holy soul has no need of our intercessory prayers, but let us pray for his eternal rest just the same, since our prayers will never go to waste.
author: Padre Pio of Pietrelcina
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Day and night I am pursued by the same thought: One does not pray enough for the dead. Eighty thousand people die in this nation every day.
author: Eugenie Smet
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is His breath that is in us, and when He wants to, He will take it away.
author: Pope Clement
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I Fear of death is for those who aren’t willing to go to Christ.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: How preposterous and absurd it is, that while we ask that the will of God should be done, yet when God calls and summons us from this world, we should not at once obey the command of His will! We struggle and resist, and like obstinate servants we are dragged into the presence of the Lord with sadness and grief, departing from this world only under the bondage of necessity and not with the obedience of a free will. Yet then we wish to be honored with heavenly rewards by the One to whom we come so unwillingly!
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Our brethren who are freed from this world by the Lord’s summons are not to be mourned, since we know that they are not lost to us, but only sent on ahead of us. Departing from us, they precede us as travelers, just as navigators are accustomed to do.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Death is not an ending, but a transition, and—this journey through time having been completed—a passage into eternity. Who would not hasten to better things?
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let death immediately stand before your eyes, and you will never desire anything bad or worldly.
author: Antony the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Our Lord was trampled on by death, and in His turn trod out a way over death. … Death slew and was slain. Death slew the natural life; and the supernatural Life slew him.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To the good man, to die is gain. The foolish fear death as the greatest of evils; the wise desire it as a rest after labors and the end of ills.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: What is death at most? It is a journey for a season, a sleep longer than usual. If you fear death, you should also fear sleep.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: On her deathbed in a foreign land, when those around her worried that she would not be buried back home with her family: Put this body away anywhere. Don’t let care about it disturb you. I ask only this of you, that you remember me at the altar of the Lord, wherever you may be. … Nothing is far from God. I need not fear that He will not know where to raise me up at the end of the world. Monica A perfect life is an imitation of death.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If we fear death before it comes, we shall conquer it when it comes.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Nothing is more certain than death, nothing more uncertain than its hour.
author: Anselm of Canterbury
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Death, the gate of life.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Blessed be God for our sister, the death of the body.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I find only one fault with you, Death: that you are too stingy with those who long for you, and too lavish with those who flee from you.
author: Catherine of Genoa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: All our whole life is but a sickness without remedy, an incurable corruption. And despite all our wrapping and plastering, bandaged up to live as long as we can, in the end we undoubtedly die of that same sickness [mortality], even though another illness may never come along. So, then, if you consider this reality well, you will look upon death not as a stranger, but as a close neighbor.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We should never look at death as something far off; for even if he seems to be in no hurry toward us, yet we ourselves never cease to hurry toward him.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In whatever way we live—whether we wake or sleep, we eat or drink, we mourn or sing—all the while we are dying.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I saw myself dying with a desire to see God, and I knew not how to seek that life other than by dying.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Life is to live in such a way that we are not afraid to die.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Everything seems to me to pass so quickly … that we must concentrate our thoughts on how to die rather than on how to live.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Of all the things of life, a happy death is our principal concern. For if we attain that, it matters little if we lose all the rest. But if we do not attain that, nothing else is of any value.
author: Juniperro Serra
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t you know that only the thoughtless and insane consider the faithful departed to be dead?
author: John Eudes
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Happy are they who, being always on their guard against death, find themselves always ready to die.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: How sweet it is to die if one has lived on the Cross!
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Think often of death, so as to prepare for it and appraise things at their true value.
author: Charles de Foucauld
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I am a prisoner too—with all this wide and beautiful creation before me, the restless soul longs to enjoy its liberty and rest beyond its bound. When the Father calls His child, how readily will He be obeyed!
author: Elizabeth Ann Seton
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: What he dieth, that must he be forever; as the tree falleth, so must it lie.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: You, if you are an apostle, will not have to die. You will move to a new house: That’s all.
author: Josemaria Escriva
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I give thanks to Almighty God that He has not considered me unworthy to be the mother of a child admitted into the heavenly kingdom. Having left the world in the white robe of his innocence, he will rejoice in the presence of God through all eternity. Clotilda To a dying friend: As your soul departs from your body, may the shining cohorts of angels hasten to greet you, the tribunal of apostles acquit you, the triumphant ranks of white-robed martyrs accompany you, the lily-bearing bands of glorious confessors surround you, the choir of virgins bring up your train with rejoicing, and in blest tranquillity may the patriarchs receive you into their loving embrace. May our Lord Jesus appear before you gentle and eager of countenance, and assign you a place amid those who stand in His presence forevermore.
author: Peter Damian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I can never lose one whom I have loved to the end. One to whom my soul cleaves so firmly that it can never be separated does not go away, but only goes before. Be mindful of me when you come to where I shall follow you.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Too much sorrow for the dead is the child of either self-love or rash judgment.
author: Robert Southwell
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Do you hate to be deceived? Then don’t deceive others.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is not in human nature to deceive others for any long time, without in a measure deceiving ourselves also.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Who is free from defects? He lacks everything who thinks he lacks nothing.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Peace and union are the most necessary of all things for men who live in common, and nothing serves so well to establish and maintain these as the forbearing charity whereby we put up with one another’s defects.
author: Robert Cardinal Bellarmine
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There is no one who is without faults, and who is not in some way a burden to others, whether he is a superior or a subject, an old man or a young one, a scholar or a dunce.
author: Robert Cardinal Bellarmine
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It’s true you have defects. But is any of this any reason for losing trust in God? Could it be His Divine Majesty doesn’t know that we’re dirt, dust, and ashes, always inclined to evil?
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Learn to hate your faults, but to hate them calmly.
author: Padre Pio of Pietrelcina
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: However great may be the temptation, if we know how to use the weapon of prayer well we shall come off conquerors at last, for prayer is more powerful than all the devils. He who is attacked by the spirits of darkness needs only to apply himself vigorously to prayer, and he will beat them back with great success.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Even the demons were not solely responsible for crucifying Him; it was you who crucified Him with them, and you continue to crucify Him by taking pleasure in your vices and sins.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Holy desire fills us only to the extent that we cut off our longings from the love of the world. You must first empty what you want to be filled. If you are to be filled with what is good, then you must pour out what is evil. … In truth, we are to be filled with Something beyond words: God Himself. We must stretch ourselves out to Him, then, so that when He comes, He may fill us.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: What a man desires, if he worships it, is to him a god. A vice in the heart is an idol on the altar. Jerome Our one desire and choice should be what is more conducive to the end for which we are created.
author: Ignatius Loyola
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He who desires anything but God deceives himself; and he who loves anything but God errs miserably.
author: Philip Neri
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t desire not to be what you are, but desire to be very well what you are.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Love heavenly desires, and desire heavenly love.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: O God, You seek those who hide from You, and hide from those who seek You!
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God said to her: I am concealing Myself from you so that you can discover by yourself what you are without Me.
author: Margaret of Cortona
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In times of desolation you should never make a change, but stand firm in the resolutions and decisions that guided you the day before the desolation.
author: Ignatius Loyola
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We need not despair of any man, as long as he lives.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When tempted to despair, I have only one recourse: to throw myself at the foot of the Tabernacle like a little dog at the feet of his master.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If I saw the gates of hell open and I stood on the brink of the abyss, I would not despair, I would not lose hope of mercy, because I would trust in You, my God.
author: Gemma Galgani
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: However wicked I may be, however great a sinner, I must hope that I will go to heaven. You forbid me to despair.
author: Charles de Foucauld
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The most beautiful Credo is the one we pronounce in our hour of darkness.
author: Padre Pio of Pietrelcina
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: World, Worldliness Don’t have Jesus Christ on your lips and the world in your hearts.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Of no use will be to me the farthest reaches of the universe or the kingdoms of this world. I would rather die and come to Jesus Christ than be king over the entire earth.
author: Ignatius Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Act as if God alone existed and nothing else.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If you can discern wisely, don’t exchange … what abides for what doesn’t abide, what never ceases for what ceases; nor truth for lies, nor body for shadow, nor watching for slumber, nor what is in season for what is out of season; nor the Time for the times.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A great crown is laid up for you, brothers; don’t barter away a great dignity for a petty pleasure.
author: Cyril of Jerusalem
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let us not esteem worldly prosperity or adversity as if they were real things or things of any importance, but let us live elsewhere, and raise all our attention to heaven; counting sin as the only true evil, and nothing truly good but virtue, which unites us to God.
author: Gregory Nazianzen
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The man who has sharp vision for God alone is blind in all the other things that attract the eyes of the multitude. … Sharp-eyed and clear-sighted is the man who looks only to the good with the single eye of his soul.
author: Gregory of Nyssa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: All the preoccupation of men with the things of this life is but the game of children on the sands. … For as soon as their labor is completed, the sand falls down and nothing is left of their buildings.
author: Gregory of Nyssa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: As no darkness can be seen by anyone surrounded by light, so no trivialities can capture the attention of anyone who has his eyes on Christ.
author: Gregory of Nyssa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Whoever seeks earth before he seeks heaven will surely lose both earth and heaven.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A detached man should always be looking to see what he can do without.
author: Henry Suso
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The whole of this present world has become mean and wearisome, and on the other hand the world to come has become so unspeakably desirable and dear that I hold all these passing things as light as thistledown.
author: Herman of Reichenau
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Man is created to praise, reverence, and serve God our Lord, and by this means to save his soul. The other things on the face of the earth are created for man to help him in attaining the end for which he is created. Hence, man is to make use of them insofar as they help him in the attainment of his end, and he must rid himself of them insofar as they prove a hindrance to him.
author: Ignatius Loyola
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The best thing must be to flee from all to the All.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The soul that journeys to God, but doesn’t shake off its cares and quiet its appetites, is like someone who drags a cart uphill.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Give me ten truly detached men, and I will convert the world with them.
author: Philip Neri
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The blessings He has given me … are scorn of the world—of its pleasures, its riches, its honors; and the love of the cross, of poverty, of humility; as well as the honor of His constant presence, of familiarity and intimacy with Him, and above all the love of His love.
author: Marie of the Incarnation
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We are pilgrims and strangers on earth. Pilgrims sleep in tents and sometimes cross deserts, but the thought of their homeland makes them forget everything else.
author: Charles de Foucauld
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God gives the Devil power against us in two modes: either for punishment when we sin, or for glory when we are tested.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Draw near to God, and Satan will flee from you.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The soul possesses freedom; and though the Devil can make suggestions, he doesn’t have the power to compel you against your will.
author: Cyril of Jerusalem
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Committing sin makes us strangers to God and partners with the Devil.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Devil’s snare doesn’t catch you unless you’re already nibbling on the Devil’s bait.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Devil often transforms himself into an angel to tempt men, some for their instruction and some for their ruin.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There’s more than one way of sacrificing to the fallen angels.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Job was turned over to the Devil to be tempted so that, by withstanding the test, he would be a torment to the Devil.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Devil has never made anyone or begotten anyone or created anyone; but whoever acts as the Devil does becomes in one sense a child of the Devil, as if begotten by him. The child resembles the father, not because they are literally kin, but because the child imitates the father.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We have been called to heal wounds, to unite what has Men apart, and to bring home those who have lost their way. Many who may seem to us to be children of the Devil will still become Christ’s disciples.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When the Devil is called the god of this world, it’s not because he made it, but because we serve him with our worldliness.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Remember that the Devil doesn’t sleep, but seeks our ruin in a thousand ways.
author: Angela Merici
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Devil never runs upon a man to seize him with his claws until he sees him on the ground, already having fallen by his own will.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The strategy of our adversary can be compared to the tactics of a commander intent upon seizing and plundering a position he desires. The leader of an army will encamp, explore the fortifications and defenses of the fortress, and attack at the weakest point. In the same way, the adversary of our human nature examines from every side all our virtues, theological, cardinal, and moral. Wherever he discovers the defenses of eternal salvation to be the weakest and most lacking, there he attacks and tries to take us by storm.
author: Ignatius Loyola
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is a mark of the evil spirit to take on the appearance of an angel of light. He begins by whispering thoughts that are suited to a devout soul, and ends by suggesting his own.
author: Ignatius Loyola
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In anything that is for the service of our Lord, the Devil tries his arts, working under the guise of holiness.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The soul that is united with God is feared by the Devil as though it were God Himself.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let the enemy rage at the gate, let him knock, let him push, let him cry, let him howl, let him do worse; we know for certain that he cannot enter save by the door of our consent.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Modem times are dominated by Satan, and will be more so in the future.
author: Maximillian Kolbe
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Devotion is a certain act of the will by which man gives himself promptly to the service of God.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Devotion is spiritual agility and liveliness, by means of which charity works in us, or we in her, with love and readiness; and as charity leads us to obey and fulfill all God’s commandments, so devotion leads us to obey them promptly and diligently.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Charity is a spiritual fire which, when it flames brightly, becomes devotion.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The ostrich never flies, the chicken flies but seldom, and then heavily and near the ground; but the swallow, the dove, and the eagle are ever on the wing; they fly far and easily. Even so sinners don’t rise to God, but always grovel on the earth in pursuing earthly things. Well-meaning people who are as yet not truly devout mount up to God in good works, but rarely, slowly, and heavily. But the devout fly to Him perpetually, soaring lightly.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If charity is milk, devotion is the cream; if charity is a plant, devotion is the flower; if charity is a precious stone, devotion is its brilliance; if charity is a costly balsam, devotion is its fragrance, an odor of sweetness, that consoles men and makes the angels rejoice.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: One man carries an ax all his life and never cuts down a tree. Another, who knows how to cut, gives a few swings and the tree is down. This ax is discretion.
author: Ammonas the Hermit
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Some wear down their bodies by fasting. But because they have no discretion, it puts them further from God.
author: Antony the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Without discretion, virtue becomes vice, and the natural impulses serve only to upset and wreck the personality.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Virtues demand discretion, and all excess is vice.
author: Bede the Venerable
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Our body is not made of iron. Our strength is not that of stone. Live and hope in the Lord, and let your service be according to reason.
author: Clare of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: DISSENT, DISSIDENTS—See Heresy, Heretics He became man so that we might be made God.
author: Athanasius of Alexandria
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: For you He entered time, so that you might become eternal.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: For men are not gods by being so in themselves, but they become gods by participation in that one God who is the true God.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God is what we ourselves aspired to be when we fell away from Him, when we listened to the voice of the seducer—“You shall be as gods”—and thus abandoned the very One who intended to make us gods, not by our desertion of Him, but by our participation in Him.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The proper effect of the Eucharist is the transformation of man into God.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: By virtue of love is the lover transformed in the beloved and the beloved is transformed in the lover. Just as hard iron in the forge takes on the color, heat, energy, and form of the fire to such a degree that it almost turns into fire, so the soul, united with God through the perfect grace of divine love, will itself become almost divine and transformed in God.
author: Angela of Foligno
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The knowledge of doctrines is a precious possession.
author: Cyril of Jerusalem
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Church doctrines are a powerful weapon; they were not sent into the world for nothing. God’s word does not return to Him void.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If a divine gift has made you suitable in genius and experience to be in doctrine the [adorner] of the spiritual tabernacle, cut out the precious gems of divine dogma, shape them faithfully, ornament them wisely, add splendor, grace, and beauty to them! By your expounding it, may that now be understood more clearly what was formerly believed in its obscurity.
author: Vincent of Lerins
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Regarding its substance, faith does not grow with the passage of time, for whatever has been believed since the beginning was contained in the faith of the ancient fathers. As regards its explication, however, the number of articles has increased, for we moderns explicitly believe what they believed implicitly.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: From the nature of the human mind, time is necessary for the full comprehension and perfection of great ideas.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Church of Christ, zealous and cautious guardian of the dogmas deposited with it, never changes any phrase of them. It does not diminish them or add to them; it neither trims what seems necessary nor grafts things superfluous; it neither gives up its own nor usurps what does not belong to it. But it devotes all its diligence to one aim: to treat tradition faithfully and wisely; to nurse and polish what from ancient times may have remained unshaped and unfinished; to consolidate and strengthen what was already clear and plain; and to guard what already was confirmed and defined.
author: Vincent of Lerins
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: From the age of fifteen, dogma has been the fundamental principle of my religion. I know of no other religion; I cannot enter into the idea of any other sort of religion; religion, as a mere sentiment, is to me a dream and a mockery.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Religion cannot but be dogmatic; it ever has been. All religions have had doctrines; all have professed to carry with them benefits which could be enjoyed only on condition of believing the word of a supernatural informant, that is, of embracing some doctrines or other.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: No doctrine is defined until it is violated.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The disbelief of Thomas has done more for our faith than the faith of the other disciples. As he touches Christ and is won over to belief, every doubt is cast aside and our faith is strengthened.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A thousand difficulties do not make a single doubt.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The dress of the body should not discredit the good of the soul.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If you style your hair sumptuously, and walk so as to draw attention in public, and attract the eyes of youth upon you, and draw the sighs of young men after you, nourishing the lust of concupiscence and inflaming the fuel of sighs—so that, although you yourself aren’t corrupted, yet you corrupt others, and offer yourself like a sword or poison to those who see you—you can’t be excused on the pretense that you’re chaste and modest in mind. Your shameful dress and immodest ornament accuse you: … You’re living in such a manner as to make yourselves objects of desire.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The purpose of clothing is to keep warm in winter and to cover your nakedness, not to serve your vanity.
author: Cyril of Jerusalem
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To change your disposition is a much greater accomplishment than to change your dress. Jerome Silk and purple and rouge and paint have beauty, but they do not impart it. … The beauty that is put on with a garment and is put off with the garment belongs without a doubt to the garment, and not to the wearer of it.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: How proud is many a man who looks down on his neighbor because the wool of his gown is finer! Yet as fine as it is, a poor sheep wore it upon her back before it came upon his back, and all the while she wore it, she was after all still only a sheep. And why should he now think himself better than she was simply by having that wool—wool that, even though it is now his, is still not so truly his as it was truly hers?
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Drunkenness is the ruin of reason. It is premature old age. It is temporary death.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The drunken man is a living corpse.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Wine is for mirth, not for madness.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In doing what we ought, we deserve no praise, because it is our duty.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Each state of life has its special duties; by accomplishing them, one may find happiness.
author: Nicholas of Flue
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Never think yourself safe because you do your duty in ninety-nine points; it is the hundredth which is to be the ground of your self-denial.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God has given me one grace—I’m not afraid of a fight; I have to do my duty, come what may. Thérèse of Lisieux Earth her joy confesses, clothing her for spring; All fresh gifts returned with her returning King. Blooms in every meadow, leaves on every bow, Speak His sorrow ended, hail His triumph now: “Welcome, happy morning!” age to age shall say.
author: Venantius Fortunatus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: ’Tis the spring of souls today: Christ hath burst His prison; And from three days’ sleep in death as a Sun hath risen. All the winter of our sins, long and dark, is flying From His light, to whom we give laud and praise undying. Now the queen of seasons, bright with the day of splendor, With the royal feast of feasts comes its joy to render!
author: John of Damascus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Now let the heavens be joyful; let earth her song begin; Let the round world keep triumph, and all that is therein! Let all things seen and unseen their notes of gladness blend, For Christ the Lord hath risen, our Joy that hath no end!
author: John of Damascus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Truly barren is a secular education. It is always in labor, but never gives birth.
author: Gregory of Nyssa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: What is nobler than to rule minds or to mold the character of the young? I consider that he who knows how to form the youthful mind is truly greater than all painters, sculptors, and all others of that sort.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He who is educated and eloquent must not measure his saintliness merely by his fluency. Of two imperfect things, holy rusticity is better than sinful eloquence. Jerome Free curiosity is of more value in learning than harsh discipline.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Anyone who wants to practice perfect poverty must renounce all worldly wisdom and even secular learning, to a certain extent. Divested of these possessions, he will be able to make the great acts of God his theme and offer himself naked to the embrace of the Crucified. Anyone who clings to his own opinions in the depths of his heart has not renounced the world perfectly.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I would rather have learning joined with virtue than all the treasures of kings.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Untilled ground, however rich, will bring forth thistles and thorns; so also the mind of man.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf
