source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We are born to love, we live to love, and we will die to love still more.
author: Joseph Cafasso
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If the Church was a body composed of different members, it couldn’t lack the noblest of all; it must have a heart, and a heart burning with love. And I realized that this love was the true motive force that enabled the other members of the Church to act; if it ceased to function, the Apostles would forget to preach the Gospel, the Martyrs would refuse to shed their blood. Thérèse of Lisieux Love … is the vocation that includes all others. Thérèse of Lisieux Love … is a universe of its own, comprising all time and space. Thérèse of Lisieux Love cannot be content without condescending—condescending to mere nothingness, and making this nothingness the fuel for its flame. Thérèse of Lisieux Even a little child can scatter flowers, to scent the throne room with their fragrance; even a little child can sing, in its shrill treble, the great canticle of Love. That shall be my life: to scatter flowers—to miss no single opportunity of making some small sacrifice, here by a smiling look, there by a kindly word, always doing the tiniest things right, and doing it for love. Thérèse of Lisieux Perfect love means putting up with other people’s shortcomings, feeling no surprise at their weaknesses, finding encouragement even in the slightest evidence of good qualities in them. Thérèse of Lisieux What is the mark of a love for God? To keep His commandments for the sake of His glory.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The good things that you love are from Him, and to the extent that they are used for Him, they will remain both good and pleasant. But the things that come from Him will be rightly turned into bitterness if they are not rightly loved—if God is forsaken because you have a greater love for what He has created.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In the long run there will be but two kinds of men: those who love God and those who love something else.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The reason for loving God is God Himself; the measure of loving God is to love Him beyond measure.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Love Him totally who gave Himself totally for your love.
author: Clare of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Give me, good Lord, such a love for You that I will love nothing in a way that displeases You, and I will love everything for Your sake.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Oh, that we might all be mad for love of Him who for love of us was called mad!
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Like the bee that sucks honey from all the wildflowers and will not use them for anything else, the soul easily extracts the sweetness of love from all the things that happen to her, that is, she loves God in them. Thus everything leads her to love always the delight of loving God.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To love God you need three hearts in one: a heart of fire for Him, a heart of flesh for your neighbor, and a heart of bronze for yourself.
author: Benedict Joseph Labre
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is always springtime in the heart that loves God.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A lustful horse and an unchaste human body should have their feed reduced. Hilarion The stuffing of the stomach is the hotbed of lust. Jerome By lust I mean that affection of the mind that aims at the enjoyment of one’s self and one’s neighbor without reference to God.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Sinful lust is not nature, but a disease of nature.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Lust indulged became habit, and habit unresisted became necessity.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The time is coming [once we are perfected in heaven] when we shall enjoy one another’s beauty without any lust.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Our relentless enemy, the teacher of fornication, whispers that God is lenient and particularly merciful to this passion, since it is so very natural. Yet if we watch the wiles of the demons, we will observe that after we have actually sinned, they will affirm that God is a just and inexorable judge. They say one thing to lead us into sin, another thing to overwhelm us in despair.
author: John Climacus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Oh, loathe the love whose final aim is lust, moth of the mind, eclipse of reason’s light; the grave of grace … the wrong of every right. In sum, an evil whose harm no tongue can tell, in which to live is death, to die is hell.
author: Robert Southwell
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The glory of God is man fully alive.
author: Irenaeus of Lyons
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God did not make the first man because He needed company, but because He wanted someone to whom He could show His generosity and love.
author: Irenaeus of Lyons
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There is a certain love deeply seated in our nature that imperceptibly knits together these bodies of ours. … Nothing so welds our life together as the love of man and wife.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The first natural tie of human society is man and wife.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Marriage is a good in which the married are better in proportion as they fear God more chastely and more faithfully, especially if they also nourish spiritually the children whom they desire carnally.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Perfect married life means the spiritual dedication of the parents for the benefit of their children.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Marriage has three blessings. The first is children, to be received and raised for God’s service. The second is the loyal faithfulness by which each serves the other. The third is the sacrament of matrimony, which signifies the inseparable union of Christ with His Church.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Even as you seek a virtuous, fair, and good spouse … it is fitting that you should be the same.
author: Bernardino of Siena
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The state of marriage is one that requires more virtue and constancy than any other. It is a perpetual exercise in mortification.
author: Frances de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: All the wealth of the world cannot be compared with the happiness of living together happily united.
author: Margaret of Youville
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: On the way to his martyrdom: How glorious to be a setting sun—setting on the world, on my way to God! May I rise in His presence!
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I am God’s wheat, and I am being ground by the teeth of wild beasts to make a pure loaf for Christ.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Now is the moment when I begin to be a disciple. May nothing seen or unseen distract me from making my way to Jesus Christ. Fire, cross, struggles with wild beasts, wrenching of bones, mangling of limbs, crushing of the whole body, cruel tortures inflicted by the Devil—let them come, provided that I make my way to Jesus Christ.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When given the choice of cursing Christ or being put to death: Eighty-six years I have served Him, and He never did me any wrong. How can I blaspheme my King and my Savior?
author: Polycarp of Smyrna
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When given the choice between death or apostasy with marriage to a pagan: I have a Bridegroom in the heavens, eternal, with all celestial glory as His dower. Febronia He cannot claim to be a martyr who has not lived in brotherly love.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Bless the martyrs heartily, that you may be a martyr by intention. Thus, even though you depart this life without persecutor, fire, or lash, you will still be found worthy of the same reward.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The ashes of martyrs drive away demons.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The martyrs were bound, imprisoned, scourged, racked, burned, tom apart, butchered—and they multiplied.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The death of the martyrs blossoms in the faith of the living.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When about to be martyred: Come, my sweetest Jesus, that I may now be inseparably united to Thee in time and eternity: Welcome ropes, hurdles, gibbets, knives, and butchery, welcome for the love of Jesus, my Savior.
author: Henry Morse
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To his captors as they led him on his way to martyrdom: Why should you bind me? From whom should I escape? From God?
author: Joseph Mukasa Balikuddembe
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To his executioners: A fountain fed from many springs will never dry up. When we are gone, others will rise in our place.
author: Bruno Serunkuma of Uganda
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: No one is a martyr for a conclusion; no one is a martyr for an opinion; it is faith that makes martyrs.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A martyrdom is a season of God’s especial power in the eye of faith, as great as if a miracle were visibly wrought.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He who is devout to the Virgin Mother will certainly never be lost.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The knot of Eve’s disobedience was loosed by the obedience of Mary. The knot which the virgin Eve tied by her unbelief, the Virgin Mary opened by her belief.
author: Irenaeus of Lyons
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: What a wonder is Your mother! The Lord entered her, and became a Servant; the Word entered her, and became silent within her; Thunder entered her, and His voice was still; the Shepherd of all entered her, and He became a Lamb in her, and came forth bleating. … The Rich went in; He came out poor; the Most High went in; He came out lowly. Brightness went into her and clothed Himself and came forth in the form of One despised … He who gives food to all went in, and got hunger; He who gives all to drink went in and got thirst. From her came forth naked and bare the One who clothes all.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Him whom the heavens cannot contain, the womb of one woman bore. She ruled our Ruler; she carried Him in whom we are; she gave milk to our Bread.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Far be it that anyone should try to defraud holy Mary of her privileges of divine grace and of her special glory. For by a certain singular favor of our Lord and God, and of her Son, she must be confessed to be the most true and most blessed Mother of God.
author: Vincent of Lerins
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A Virgin conceived, a Virgin bore, and a Virgin she remains.
author: Peter Chrysologus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A gentle maiden, having lodged a God in her womb, asks as its price: peace for the world, salvation for those who are lost, and life for the dead.
author: Peter Chrysologus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The God whom earth and sea and sky adore and laud and magnify, Whose might they own, whose praise they tell, in Mary’s body deigned to dwell. O Mother blest! And chosen shrine wherein the Architect divine Whose hand contains the earth and sky vouchsafed in hidden guise to lie; Blest in the message Gabriel brought; blest in the work the Spirit wrought; Most blest, to bring to human birth the long desired of all the earth!
author: Venantius Fortunatus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: O blessed and ever-blessed Virgin, by whose blessing not only is every creature blessed by its Creator, but the Creator is blessed by the creature!
author: Anselm of Canterbury
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In dangers, in doubts, in difficulties, think of Mary, call upon Mary. Don’t let her name depart from your lips; never allow it to leave your heart. And that you may more surely obtain the assistance of her prayer, don’t neglect to walk in her footsteps.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If the hurricanes of temptation rise against you, or you are running upon the rocks of trouble, look to the star—call on Mary!
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It was fitting for the Queen of Virgins, by a singular privilege of sanctity, to lead a life entirely free from sin, so that while she ministered to the Destroyer of death and sin, she should obtain the gift of life and justice for all.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I greet you, Lady, Holy Queen, Holy Mary, Mother of God, Virgin who became the Church, chosen by the most holy Father of heaven; consecrated to holiness through His most holy and beloved Son and the Holy Spirit, the Comforter. In you was and is the whole fullness of grace and everything that is good.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: No angel, no saint, can equal her in the multitude and accumulation of heavenly good things. Bonaventure As sailors are guided by a star to the port, so Christians are guided to heaven by Mary.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Eve sought the fruit, but did not find there what she wished for. In her fruit the blessed Virgin found all that Eve had wanted.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Blessed Virgin, by becoming the mother of God, received a kind of infinite dignity because God is infinite; this dignity therefore is such a reality that a better one is not possible, just as nothing can be better than God.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There is no sinner in the world, however much at enmity with God, who cannot recover God’s grace by recourse to Mary, and by asking her assistance.
author: Bridget of Sweden
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When a fire is kindled and many logs surround it, the log most apt and efficient for combustion will be the quickest to catch the flame and bum. So it was with Mary. For when the fire of divine love—which in itself is changeless and eternal—began to kindle and appear, and when the Godhead willed to become incarnate, no creature was more apt and efficient for receiving this fire of love than the Virgin Mary; for no creature burned with such charity as she.
author: Bridget of Sweden
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Behold the power of the Virgin Mother: She wounded and took captive the heart of God.
author: Bernardino of Siena
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: As flies are driven away by a great fire, so were the evil spirits driven away by her ardent love for God.
author: Bernardino of Siena
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Hail, God’s palace; hail, tabernacle of the Most High; hail, house of God; hail, His holy vestments; hail, handmaid of God!
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Only after the Last Judgment will Mary get any rest; from now until then, she is much too busy with her children.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: All our perfection consists in being conformed, united, and consecrated to Jesus Christ; and therefore the most perfect of all devotions is, without any doubt, that which most perfectly conforms, unites, and consecrates us to Jesus Christ. Now, Mary being the most conformed of all creatures to Jesus Christ, it follows that of all devotions, that which most consecrates and conforms the soul to our Lord is devotion to His holy Mother, and that the more a soul is consecrated to Mary, the more it is consecrated to Jesus.
author: Louis de Montfort
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We consecrate ourselves at one and the same time to the most holy Virgin and to Jesus Christ: to the most holy Virgin as to the perfect means that
author: Jesus Christ
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Himself has chosen by which to unite Himself to us, and us to Him; and to our Lord as to our Last End, to whom as our Redeemer and our God, we owe all we are.
author: Louis de Montfort
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Mary is the heart of the Church. This is why all works of charity spring from her. It is well known that the heart has two movements: systole and diastole. Thus Mary is always performing these two movements: absorbing grace from her Most Holy Son, and pouring it forth on sinners.
author: Anthony Mary Claret
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The weapon of the second Eve and Mother of God is prayer.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In her, the destinies of the world were to be reversed, and the serpent’s head bruised. In her was bestowed the greatest honor ever put upon any individual of our fallen race. God was taking upon Him her flesh, and humbling Himself to be called her offspring—such is the deep mystery!
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Mother dear, lend me your heart. I look for it each day to pour my troubles into.
author: Gemma Galgani
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We in our exile have sent on ahead of us our advocate who, as mother of our Judge and mother of mercy, will humbly and effectively look after everything that concerns our salvation. Today earth has sent a priceless gift up to heaven, so that by giving and receiving within the blessed bond of friendship, the human is wedded to the divine, earth to heaven, the depths to the heights. … Blessed indeed is Mary, blessed in many ways, both in receiving the Savior, and in being received by the Savior.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: And who, I ask, could believe that the ark of holiness, the dwelling place of the Word of God, the temple of the Holy Spirit, could be reduced to ruin? My soul is filled with horror at the thought that this virginal flesh that had begotten God, had brought Him into the world, had nourished and carried Him, could have been turned into ashes or given over to be the food of worms.
author: Robert Cardinal Bellarmine
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Today, the reformation of our nature begins, and the aging world is transformed anew to the divine likeness and receives the beginnings of a second formation by God.
author: Andrew of Crete
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Assuredly, she who played the part of the Creator’s servant and mother is in all strictness and truth in reality God’s mother and lady and queen over all created things.
author: John of Damascus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To serve Mary and to be her courtier is the greatest honor one can possibly possess, for to serve the Queen of Heaven is already to reign there, and to live under her commands is more than to govern.
author: John of Damascus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Just as Mary surpassed in grace all others on earth, so also in heaven is her glory unique. If eye has not seen or ear heard or the human heart conceived what God has prepared for those who love Him [1 Cor 2:9], who can express what He has prepared for the woman who gave Him birth and who loved Him, as everyone knows, more than anyone else?
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: She has surpassed the riches of the virgins, the confessors, the martyrs, the apostles, the prophets, the patriarchs, and the angels, for she herself is the first-fruit of the virgins, the mirror of confessors, the rose of martyrs, the ruler of apostles, the oracle of prophets, the daughter of patriarchs, the queen of angels. Bonaventure No one has access to the Almighty as His mother has; none has merit such as hers. Her Son will deny her nothing that she asks; and herein lies her power. While she defends the Church, neither height nor depth, neither men nor evil spirits, neither great monarchs, nor craft of man, nor popular violence, can avail to harm us; for human life is short, but Mary reigns above, a Queen forever.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Magdalene, most of all, is the model I like to follow. That boldness of hers, which would be so amazing if it weren’t the boldness of a lover, won the heart of Jesus, and how it fascinates mine! Thérèse of Lisieux THE MASS—See Liturgy God knows how to bring it about that a man enjoys meditation as if he were going to a dance. Or on the other hand, He knows how to let one experience meditation as if struggling in battle.
author: Nicholas of Flue
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Above all I recommend to you always, recollection, that holy solitude, that inner sacred desert in which your soul ought always to be alone in the bosom of the heavenly Father, in the silence of faith and holy love.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God turns Himself away, not so much from those who sin, as from those who aren’t stricken with fear after they sin.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Our Lord came first as Medicine, not as Judge. For if He had come to judge first, He would have found no one on whom He might bestow the rewards of righteousness. Since, then, He saw that all were sinners, and that no one was exempt from the sentence of death that followed sin, His mercy had to be sought first, before His judgment could be executed.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: No one should feel secure in this life, because the whole of it is one long test; and no one who is able to pass from a worse state to a better one can be certain that he will not later also pass from a better state to a worse. Our only hope, our only confidence, our only assured promise, Lord, is Your mercy.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God never deserts a man, unless first He is deserted by that man. For even if a man shall have committed grievous sins once, and twice, and a third time, God still looks for him, just as He says through the prophet, “so that he may be converted and live.”
author: Caesarius of Arles
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God has promised pardon to the one who repents, but He has not promised repentance to the one who sins.
author: Anselm of Canterbury
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Mercy is the fulfillment of justice, not its abolition.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If someone, at the Devil’s prompting, had committed every sin against God and then, with true contrition and the intention of amendment, truly repented these sins and humbly, with burning love, asked God for mercy, there is no doubt that the kind and merciful God Himself would immediately be as ready to receive that person back into His grace with great joy and happiness as would be a loving father who saw returning to him his only, dearly beloved son, now freed from a great scandal and a most shameful death.
author: Bridget of Sweden
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: No mother could snatch her child from a burning building more swiftly than God is constrained to succor a penitent soul.
author: Henry Suso
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Since God displayed His great mercy in so many ways even toward Judas, an apostle turned traitor, since He invited him so often to be forgiven and did not allow him to perish except through despair alone, surely there is no cause for anyone in this life to despair even of an imitator of Judas.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Where is the foolish person who would think it in his power to commit a sin more than God could forgive?
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Our sins are nothing but a grain of sand alongside the great mountain of the mercy of God.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Had He so pleased, He might have found, when we sinned, other beings to do Him service, casting us into hell; but He purposed to save and to change us.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Those who crucified our Lord supposed when He was dead that His signs had died with Him. But His signs manifestly continued to live through His disciples, so that the murderers might know that the Lord of the signs was living.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If God has given you the power, go ahead and work a miracle; that’s why He gave you the power. But don’t think that those who have never worked a miracle aren’t part of the kingdom of God.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God is always almighty; He can at all times work miracles, and He would work them now as in the days of old were it not that faith is lacking!
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The incarnation is the most stupendous event which ever can take place on earth; and after it and henceforth, I do not see how we can scruple at any miracle on the mere ground of its being unlikely to happen.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Undoubtedly, were anyone to attempt the task of collecting together all the errors that have been broached against the faith and to concentrate into one the sap and substance of them all, he could not succeed in doing so better than the Modernists have done. No, they have gone further than this, for … their system means the destruction not of the Catholic religion alone, but of all religion.
author: Pope Pius
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: X MONEY—See Wealth MONKS—See Religious life The mortified man is able to suck honey from the rock and oil from the rugged stones.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The soul should treat the body as its child, correcting without hurting it.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Certain virtues are greatly esteemed and always preferred by the general run of men because they are close at hand, easily noticed, and in effect material. Thus many people prefer bodily to spiritual alms; hairshirts, fasting, going barefoot, using the discipline, and physical mortifications to meekness, patience, modesty, and other mortifications of the heart, although the latter are really higher virtues.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: They who pay a moderate attention to the mortification of their bodies and direct their main attention to mortify the will and understanding, even in the matters of the slightest moment, are more to be esteemed than those who give themselves exclusively to bodily penances.
author: Philip Neri
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The perfection of a Christian consists in mortifying himself for the love of Christ. Where there is no great mortification, there is no great sanctity.
author: Philip Neri
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The best way not to find the bed too cold is to go to bed colder than the bed is.
author: Charles Cardinal Borromeo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The practices of mortification should be modified by prudence and the advice of a wise director, because it often happens that the Devil urges a soul to excessive penances to tire her and render her unfit for the service of God and the fulfillment of her duties.
author: Anna Maria Taigi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In the convent we are without shoes and stockings; we shall see if we can stand it. It’s certain that on the one hand, we don’t want to pamper anyone, but on the other hand, we don’t want to kill anyone, either.
author: Mary Magdalen Bentivoglio
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When we say this thing is a mystery, of the thing we say nothing, but of ourselves we say that we do not comprehend this thing—as defect of strength in us makes some weights to be immobile, so likewise defect of understanding makes some truths to be mysterious.
author: Elizabeth Ann Seton
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Mysteries in religion are measured by the proud according to their own capacity; by the humble, according to the power of God: the humble glorify God for them, the proud exalt themselves against them.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A revelation is religious doctrine viewed on its illuminated side; a mystery is the selfsame doctrine viewed on the side unilluminated.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: THE NATIVITY OF CHRIST—See Christmas You make a virtue of necessity. Jerome Necessity has no law.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When you see your brother, you see God.
author: Clement of Alexandria
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The sign that you love God is this: that you love your fellow. And if you hate your fellow, your hatred is toward God.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If you are angry at your neighbor, you are angry at God. … Honor your neighbor, and you have honored God.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: From our neighbor are life and death. If we do good to our neighbor, we do good to God; if we cause our neighbor to stumble, we sin against Christ.
author: Anthony the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Suppose we were to … draw the outline of a circle. … Let us suppose that this circle is the world, and that God Himself is the center; the straight lines drawn from the circumference are the lives of men. … The closer those lines are to God, the closer they become to one another; and the closer they are to one another, the closer they become to God.
author: Dorotheas of Gaza
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God said: I have placed you in the midst of your fellows so that you may do to them what you cannot do to Me—that is, so that you may love your neighbor freely without expecting any return from him. And what you do to him I count as done to Me.
author: Catherine of Siena
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is impossible to fulfill the law concerning love for Me, God eternal, apart from the law concerning love for your neighbors. These are the two feet of affection on which you must follow the commandments and counsels given you by Christ crucified.
author: Catherine of Siena
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We cannot be sure whether we are loving God, although we may have good reasons for believing that we are. But we can know quite well whether we are loving our neighbor.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Though we do not have our Lord with us in bodily presence, we have our neighbor; who, for the ends of love and loving service, is as good as our Lord Himself.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t think that, because the particular virtues you have in mind don’t shine in your neighbor, he won’t be precious in God’s sight for something you’re not thinking about.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We can never love our neighbor too much.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Novelists are generally great liars.
author: Jean Baptiste de la Salle
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Far, far from the clergy be the love of novelty! God hates the proud and the obstinate mind.
author: Pope Pius
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: X NUNS—See Religious Life; Virgins, Consecrated God did not tell us to follow Him because He needed our help, but because He knew that loving Him would make us whole.
author: Irenaeus of Lyons
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Whoever doesn’t have one Master has many.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Attempts to be virtuous that are joined to disobedience to the will of God, no matter how good they may appear, will actually work for our damnation.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: No man may legitimately do what God has forbidden nor leave undone what God has commanded by claiming that he does so according to his own private understanding of what reverence or devotion requires. For this would be an imprudent devotion, and an irreverent reverence, and not at all a proper humility. It is instead only an unrecognized pride to stand stubbornly against God’s will and to disobey His pleasure.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God desires the least degree of obedience and submissiveness more than all those services you think of rendering Him.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t think that pleasing God lies so much in doing a great deal as in doing it with good will, without possessiveness and the approval of men.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: What does it profit you to give God one thing if He asks of you another? Consider what it is God wants, and then do it.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The mind [must be] ever on the alert to discover the indications of Providence, and the will prepared to carry them out.
author: Vincent de Paul
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: You must refuse nothing you recognize to be His will.
author: Jane Frances de Chantal
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Obedience is the only virtue that implants the other virtues in the heart and preserves them after they have been so implanted.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Obedience is the sepulcher of the will and the resurrection of lowliness.
author: John Climacus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Obedience is the perfection of the religious life; by it man submits to man for the love of God, as God rendered Himself obedient unto men for their salvation.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Devil doesn’t fear austerity but holy obedience.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Obedience is a little dog that leads the blind.
author: Joseph of Cupertino
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If a man begins to continue in his sins, despair is born of the multitude of those sins, and obstinacy is begotten of despair. … God does not compel anyone to be obstinate; obstinacy results rather from His indulgence and forgiveness. Thus it must be believed that it was not divine power but divine patience that hardened Pharaoh.
author: Caesarius of Arles
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He who loses an opportunity is like the man who lets a bird fly from his hand, for he will never recover it.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: What can be a more spiritual prayer than the one that was given to us by Christ, who also gave us the Holy Spirit? What prayer to the Father can be more truthful than the one that was delivered to us by the Son who is Truth, from His own mouth? … Let us therefore, beloved brothers, pray as God our Teacher has taught us. It is a loving and friendly prayer to beseech God with His own word, to approach His ears in the prayer of Christ. Let the Father acknowledge the words of His Son when we make our prayer, and let the One who dwells within our breast Himself also dwell in our voice. And since we have Him as an Advocate with the Father for our sins, when as sinners we petition on behalf of our sins, let us put forward the words of our Advocate.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We don’t say “My Father, who art in heaven,” nor “Give me this day my daily bread”; nor does each one ask that only his own debt should be forgiven him; nor does he request for himself alone that he may not be led into temptation and may be delivered from evil. Our prayer is public and common; and when we pray, we pray not for one, but for the whole people, because we the whole people are one.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: What mysteries are contained in the Our Father! How many and how great are they, collected briefly in words, but spiritually abundant in virtue! There is absolutely nothing passed over that is not comprehended in these our prayers and petitions—a summary of heavenly doctrine!
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It ought to excite us to praise God exceedingly when we consider the great excellence of this heavenly prayer, composed as it was so well by such a good Master, so that, daughters, every one of us may apply it to our needs. I am astonished to see how every kind of contemplation and perfection is comprised in such few words; for if we study only this book, we seem to stand in need of no other. Herein our Lord has already taught us every kind of prayer.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

topic: THE OUR FATHER AND HAIL MARY
quote: At each word of the Our Father, Hail Mary, and Glory Be, I glimpse an abyss of goodness and mercy.
author: Anthony Mary Claret
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Sometimes, when I’m in such a state of spiritual dryness that I can’t find a single thought in my mind that will bring me close to God, I say an Our Father and a Hail Mary very slowly indeed. How they take me out of myself then! Thérèse of Lisieux A movement of the soul contrary to nature in the sense of disobedience to reason: that is what passions are.
author: Clement of Alexandria
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: For each of our impulses, when it takes control, becomes the master and we the slave. Like a tyrant it seizes the citadel of the soul, and by means of its underlings plays havoc with its subjects, using our own thoughts as the servants of its good pleasure.
author: Gregory of Nyssa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Anger, fear, cowardice, arrogance, pleasure, grief, hatred, spite, heartless cruelty, jealousy, flattery, bearing grudges and resentment, and all the other hostile drives within us: There is your array of the masters and tyrants that try to enslave the soul, their prisoner of war, and bring it under their control.
author: Gregory of Nyssa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A man who governs his passions is master of the world. We must either command them, or be commanded by them. It is better to be a hammer than an anvil. Dominic Patient endurance is the perfection of charity.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Patience is the companion of wisdom.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Patience is the root and guardian of all the virtues.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let your understanding strengthen your patience. In serenity look forward to the joy that follows sadness.
author: Peter Damian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We can never know how patient or humble someone is when everything is going well with him. But when those who should cooperate with him do exactly the opposite, then we can know. A man has as much patience and humility as he has then, and no more.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He submitted Himself to the elements, to cold and heat, hunger and thirst … concealing His power and giving it up, taking on the likeness of man, so that He might teach us weak and wretched mortals with what patience we ought to bear tribulation.
author: Angela of Foligno
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Patient endurance attains to all things. The one who possesses God is lacking in nothing; God alone is enough.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When you encounter difficulties and contradictions, don’t try to break them, but bend them with gentleness and time.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Have patience with all the world, but first of all with yourself.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When you are excited to impatience, think for a moment how much more reason God has to be angry with you, than you can have for anger against any human being; and yet how constant is His patience and forbearance.
author: Elizabeth Anne Seton
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Peace … is the tranquillity of order.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Belligerents are not reluctant to have peace, but they want a peace to their own liking.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Peace is always in God, for God is peace and peace cannot be destroyed, but discord is destroyed.
author: Nicholas of Flue
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Lord, make me an instrument of your peace; where there is hatred, let me sow love; where there is injury, pardon; where there is doubt, faith; where there is despair, hope; where there is darkness, light; and where there is sadness, joy. O Divine Master, grant that I may not so much seek to be consoled as to console; to be understood as to understand; to be loved as to love; for it is in giving that we receive, it is in pardoning that we are pardoned, and it is in dying that we are born to eternal life.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Peace is better than a fortune.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Christian has a deep, silent, hidden peace, which the world sees not, like some well in a retired and shady place.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: PENANCE—See Confession, Penance The Church and the world have need of a new Pentecost, a second Pentecost, a priestly Pentecost, an interior Pentecost.
author: Concepcion Cabrera de Armida
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: By the perfect exercise of only one virtue, a man may attain to the height of all the rest.
author: Gregory Nazianzen
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: No one is suddenly made perfect.
author: Bede the Venerable
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Perfection does not consist in consolation, but rather in the submission of our wills to God—above all, in desolation.
author: Henry Suso
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Our perfection certainly consists in knowing God and ourselves.
author: Angela of Foligno
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Perfection: Is it not a loving, sweet union of the will with that of God?
author: Vincent de Paul
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There are certain souls who desire to arrive at perfection all at once, and this desire keeps them constantly unsettled. It is necessary first to cling to the feet of Jesus, then to kiss His sacred hands, and at last you may find your way into His divine heart.
author: Alphonsus Liguori
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We can never attain to perfection while we have an affection for any imperfection.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t wish to be anything but what you are, and try to be that perfectly.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We must not be disturbed at our imperfections, since for us perfection consists in fighting against them. How can we fight against them unless we see them, or overcome them unless we face them?
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t worry about your perfection, or about your soul. God to whom it belongs, and to whom you have completely entrusted it, will take care of it and fill it with all the graces, consolations and blessings of His holy love in the measure that they will be useful in this life.
author: Jane Frances de Chantal
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Walk in the good, believe in God, don’t try to acquire perfection by force, but do everything quietly and then you will be truly humble. God will give you everything.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The highest perfection is to nourish yourself on the divine will in a spirit of pure faith and love.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Christian perfection consists in three things: praying heroically, working heroically, and suffering heroically.
author: Anthony Mary Claret
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Be devoted to God and do not fear, for no wounds can come to those who follow Christ. Even if they take away the life of your body, Christ is still with you.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is frequently in pain of the body, amid the very hands of persecutors, that Christ is really found. … In a little while, in a brief moment, when you have escaped the hands of your persecutors, and have not given in to the ways of the world, Christ will meet you and will not allow you to be tempted further.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Nothing is more to be feared than too long a peace. You are deceived if you think that a Christian can live without persecution. He suffers the greatest persecution of all who lives under none. A storm puts a man on his guard and obliges him to exert his utmost efforts to avoid shipwreck. Jerome The instance cannot be found in the history of mankind, in which an anti- Christian power could long abstain from persecution.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The woman who stayed behind [at the tomb] to seek Christ was the only one who saw Him. For perseverance is essential to any good deed, as the Voice of truth tells us: “Whoever perseveres to the end will be saved” [Mt 10:22].
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We ought to make some progress, however little, every day, and show some increase of fervor. We ought to act as if we were at war—as, indeed, we are—and never relax until we have won the victory.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let me get through today, and I shall not fear tomorrow.
author: Philip Neri
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: My Jesus, if You uphold me, I shall not fall.
author: Philip Neri
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Though perseverance does not come from our power, yet it comes within our power.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The little daily lesson: to keep soberly and quietly in His Presence, trying to turn every little action on His Will; and to praise and love through cloud and sunshine is all my care and study.
author: Elizabeth Ann Seton
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: O foundation of the Church blessed in calling him by this new name, O rock worthy to be built upon, which will dissolve the laws of hell, the gates of Tartarus, and all the bonds of death! O blessed doorkeeper of heaven, to whose judgment the keys of access to eternity are committed, whose earthly sentence is binding authority in heaven.
author: Hilary of Poitiers
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is to Peter himself that He says: “You are Peter, and upon this rock I will build My Church” [Mt 16:18]. Where Peter is, there is the Church. And where the Church is, no death is there, but eternal life.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Peter, the leader of the choir, the mouth of all the apostles, the head of that tribe, the ruler of the whole world, the foundation of the Church, the ardent lover of Christ.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A saint was once asked, while playing happily with his companions, what he would do if an angel told him that in a quarter of an hour he would die and have to appear before the judgment seat of God. The saint promptly replied that he would continue playing because he was certain these games were pleasing to God.
author: John Bosco
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Poetry is the wine of devils.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Poets and philosophers are alike in being big with wonder.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Church herself is the most sacred and august of poets.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Nations don’t rise to supremacy through merit; their fortunes vary at random.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When did a royal alliance ever begin in good faith or end without bloodshed?
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To the Roman imperial prefect about to execute him for his faith: The glory we look forward to is spiritual, heavenly, not of this world, for this world passes away, and all the glory of it. But what is laid up for us in the heavens is eternal, which God has prepared for those who believe in Him. And what are you and your princes, but smoke that is blown away by the storm?
author: Venantius of Camerino
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Rulers are custodians of the decrees of God.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is right to submit to higher authority whenever a command of God would not be violated.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The difference between good and bad emperors is that the good love freedom; the bad, slavery.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Rulers are happy if they rule justly.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If justice is taken away, then, what are kingdoms but great robberies?
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Paraphrasing the Roman orator Cicero: A first-rate power will not engage in war except either for honor or for safety.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God overthrows the thrones of those who are disobedient to His law.
author: Avitus of Vienna
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Sanctify yourself, and you will sanctify society.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let the holy one pray, and the prudent one rule.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The government of tyrants cannot last long because it is hateful to the multitude, and what is against the wishes of the multitude cannot long be preserved.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Christian is bound to obey the authorities when their power is from God, but not otherwise.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Human government is derived from the divine government and should imitate it.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The purpose of temporal tranquillity, which well-ordered policies establish and maintain, is to give opportunities for contemplating truth.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The world would have peace if only the men of politics would follow the Gospels.
author: Bridget of Sweden
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: My political views are those of the Our Father.
author: John Bosco
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If He turns their poisonous joys into bitterness, if He corrupts their pleasures, and if He scatters thorns along the path of their riot, paths hitherto strewn with the roses of laughter, the reason is that He loves them still. And this is the holy cruelty of the Physician, who, in extreme cases of sickness, makes us take most bitter and most horrible medicines. … The greatest mercy of God is not to let those nations remain in peace with each other who are not at peace with God.
author: Padre Pio of Pietrelcina
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When you have pity on the poor, you lend to God; and whoever gives to the least, gives to God—a sweet-smelling spiritual sacrifice to Him.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: After selling his copy of the Gospels and giving the money to those who were hungry: I have sold the book that told me to sell all that I had and give to the poor. Serapion The bread you store up belongs to the hungry; the cloak that lies in your chest belongs to the naked; the gold that you have hidden in the ground belongs to the poor.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let us relieve the poverty of those who beg from us; and if they impose upon us, let us not be over-exact about it.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Love knows that among the poor, and especially among the blind, there are people who shine like the sun, cleansed by their endurance and the ills they have suffered.
author: Simeon the Insane
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Whoever curses a poor man does an injury to Christ, whose noble image he wears—the image of Him who made Himself poor for us in this world.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Even though the poor are often rough and unrefined, we must not judge them from external appearances nor from the mental gifts they seem to have received. On the contrary, if you consider the poor in the light of faith, then you will observe that they are taking the place of the Son of God who chose to be poor.
author: Vincent de Paul
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: By pointing out the tradition which that very great, oldest, and well-known Church—founded and established at Rome by those two most glorious apostles, Peter and Paul—received from the apostles, I can put to shame all of those who in any way, either through wicked self-conceit, or through vainglory, or through blind and evil opinion, gather together in a way they should not. For every Church must be in harmony with this Church because of its outstanding pre-eminence, that is, the faithful from everywhere, since the apostolic tradition is preserved in it by those from everywhere.
author: Irenaeus of Lyons
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is on Peter that He builds the Church, and to him that He entrusts the sheep to feed. And although He assigns a like power to all the Apostles, yet He founded a single chair, thus establishing by His own authority the source and hallmark of the Church’s unity.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If a man does not hold fast to this unity of Peter, does he imagine that he still holds the faith? If he deserts the chair of Peter upon whom the Church was built, does he still have confidence that he is in the Church?
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To Pope Damasus: I follow no leader but Christ and join in communion with none but Your Blessedness, that is, with the chair of Peter. I know that this is the rock on which the Church has been built. Whoever eats the Lamb outside this house is profane. Anyone who is not in the ark of Noah will perish when the flood prevails. Jerome Reckon up the priests from the days that Peter sat, and in their ancestral ranks note who succeeded whom; for that is the Rock over which the gates of hell shall never prevail.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Rome has spoken; the matter is settled.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Roman Church has never erred and, according to Scripture, never shall err.
author: Pope Gregory VII
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Only the Church of Peter, to whose lot fell Italy when the disciples were sent out to preach, has always stood fast in the faith. While the faith has disappeared or has partly decayed in other regions, the Church of Peter still flourishes in faith and free from heresy.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To Pope Gregory XI: Take care that I do not have to complain about you to Jesus crucified. There is no one else I can complain to, for you have no superior on earth.
author: Catherine of Siena
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He is rich enough who is poor in Christ. Jerome A man’s poverty before God is judged by the disposition of his heart, not by his coffers.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Poverty was not found in heaven. It abounded on earth, but man did not know its value. The Son of God, therefore, treasured it and came down from heaven to choose it for Himself, to make it precious to us.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: No man should commend poverty unless he is poor.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux Poverty
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I love, but not dirt.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If we had any possessions, we would be forced to have arms to protect them, since possessions are a cause of disputes and strife, and in many ways we would be hindered from loving God and our neighbor. Therefore in this life we wish to have no temporal possessions.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Poverty is the special way of salvation. It is the source of humility and the root of all perfection, and its fruit is manifold, though unseen. This is the treasure hidden in the field in the Gospel, to buy which we must sell all— and anything that cannot be sold should be abandoned for love of it.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To desire to be poor but not to be inconvenienced by poverty, is to desire the honor of poverty and the convenience of riches.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Alas! I have nothing to bequeath to you but my bad example.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Try to practice real poverty of spirit. Live completely detached from every consolation of sense, both within and without, to prevent falling into the trap of spiritual gluttony. It is necessary to live detached from your own pleasure, from your own way of thinking and feeling, so as not to fall prey to spiritual dilettantism.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
