quote: Read the words of Holy Scripture by means of deeds.
author: Mark the Ascetic
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If you would heed the Word of life, cut yourself off from evil things. The hearing of the Word profits nothing to the one who is busy with sins.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The study of the inspired Scripture is the chief way of finding our duty.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Every word and deed should be ratified by the testimony of the Holy Scripture, to confirm those who do good and to shame those who do evil.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Just as at sea, those who are carried away from the direction of the harbor bring themselves back on course by a clear sign, so Scripture may guide those adrift on the sea of life back into the harbor of the divine will.
author: Gregory of Nyssa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There is a mirror, a spiritual one … that not only shows us our own deformity, but transforms it too—if we are willing—into surpassing beauty. This mirror is the memory of good men, and the history of their blessed lives; the reading of the Scriptures; the laws given by God.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We ought not, as soon as we leave church, to plunge into business unsuited to church, but as soon as we get home, we should take the Scriptures into our hands, and call our wife and children to join us in putting together what we have heard.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Anyone who has received a few coins puts them in a purse and seals it. But we, having been given oracles more precious than gold or costly stones, and receiving the treasures of the Spirit, fail to put them away in the storehouses of our soul! Instead, we thoughtlessly allow them to escape at random from our minds. Who then will pity us, plotting against our own interests, plunging ourselves into so deep a poverty?
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Divine Scripture is the feast of wisdom, and the individual books are the various dishes.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Ignorance of the Scriptures is ignorance of Christ. Jerome Let sleep find you holding your Bible, and when your head nods, let it be resting on a sacred page. Jerome The one who is well grounded in the testimonies of the Scripture is the bulwark of the Church. Jerome
author: Let Your
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Scriptures be my chaste delight. Don’t let me be deceived by them or deceive others using them.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A letter from our fatherland.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Study your heart in the light of the Holy Scriptures, and you will know therein who you were, who you are, and who you ought to be.
author: Fulgence of Ruspe
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Holy Scripture by the manner of its language transcends every science, because in one and the same sentence, while it describes a fact, it reveals a mystery.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Scripture is a stream in which the elephant may swim and the lamb may wade.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Store up in your minds the Lord’s words that you receive through your ears, for the Word of the Lord is the nourishment of the mind. When His Word is heard but not stored away in the memory, it is like food that has been eaten and then rejected by an upset stomach. A man’s life is despaired of if he cannot retain his food; in the same way, if you receive the food of holy exhortations, but fail to store in your memory those words of life that nurture righteousness, you have good reason to fear the danger of everlasting death.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is good to read the testimonies of Scripture; it is good to seek the Lord our God in them. As for me, however, I have already made so much of Scripture my own that I have more than enough to meditate on and turn over in my mind. I need no more … I know Christ, the poor crucified One.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Saint Paul tells us, “The letter kills, but the spirit gives life” [2 Cor 3:6]. A man has been killed by the letter of the Sacred Scripture when he wants to quote it only so that people will think him to be very learned, … when he has no desire to follow the spirit of Sacred Scripture, but wants to know what it says only so he can explain it to others.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is one of the glories of the Scripture that it can embrace many meanings in a single passage.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Each man marvels to find in the divine Scriptures truths that he himself has thought out.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: By the secret counsel of the Holy Spirit, the Scriptures have been crafted in such a way that they are plain and simple enough for every man to find in them what he needs to understand. Yet again, they are so lofty and difficult that no man is so cunning that he won’t find there things far beyond his reach, things far too deep to fathom.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God’s word is so rich that it is a treasury of every good. From it flow faith, hope, love, and all the virtues, the many gifts of the Spirit.
author: Lawrence of Brindisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God’s Word is light to the mind and fire to the will so that a person may know and love the Lord. To the interior person who lives by the Spirit, it is bread and water, but a bread sweeter than any honey from the comb, and water more delicious than milk or wine.
author: Lawrence of Brindisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Learn to fix the eye of faith on the divine word of the Holy Scriptures as on “a light shining in a dark place until the day dawns and the day-star arises in our hearts” [2 Pet 1:19]. For the ineffable Source from which this lamp borrows its light is the Light that “shines in darkness, but the darkness does not comprehend it” [Jn 1:5]. To see it, our hearts must be purified by faith.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: No matter how lowly a man may be, if he will seek his way through the Scripture with the staff of faith in his hand; and hold that staff, and search out his way with it; and have the holy, ancient teachers of the Church for his guides as well; making his way with good intentions and a lowly heart; using reason and refusing no good learning; calling on God for wisdom, grace, and help that he may keep his way and follow his good guides; then he will never fall into danger, but will wade through surely and well. And he will come to the end of his journey at the place for which he was searching.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If a man will not take the teachings of the Catholic faith as a rule of interpretation when he studies the Scripture—but instead, being distrustful, studies the Scripture to find out whether or not the faith of the Church is true—he cannot fail to fall into errors.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Church of Christ has always, and never fails in, the right understanding of Scripture, so far as is necessary for our salvation.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If a man should doubt the knowledge and understanding of anything written in the Scripture, he is not wise then to take upon himself the authority to interpret, boldly depending on his own mind. Instead, he should depend on the interpretation of the holy teachers and the saints of old, and on the interpretation that has been received and allowed by the universal Church. For it was the Church through which the Scripture has come into our hands and been delivered to us in the first place, and without the Church, as Saint Augustine says, we could not know which books were Holy Scripture.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: From whom did you receive the Sacred Books? From the Church. Which? The Catholic. Then before you can be certain of the authenticity and truthfulness of Sacred Scripture, you must first know which is the true Catholic Church.
author: Dominic Barberi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Fly from scruples as from a pestilence; they make the soul lose immense treasures.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Seeing God means following Him wherever He might lead.
author: Gregory of Nyssa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Every little glimpse of God that can be gained exceeds every pain and every joy that man can conceive without it.
author: Catherine of Genoa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: One must see God in everyone.
author: Catherine Laboure
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Lord, You called to me and cried aloud, and You broke through my deafness. You flashed, and shone, and chased away my blindness. You breathed upon me fragrantly; I drew in my breath, and now I pant for You. I tasted, and now I hunger and thirst for You. You touched me, and I burned to enjoy Your peace.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He alone is God who can never be sought in vain: not even when He cannot be found.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Whenever you seek truth, you seek God, whether or not you know it.
author: Edith Stein
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Control your tongue and your belly.
author: Anthony the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Those whose will always inclines to self-indulgence refuse to do even what is in their power under the pretext that they have no help from above.
author: Mark the Ascetic
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let us live soberly. For through our bodily senses, whether we wish it or not, robbers come in. The inside of the house is sure to be blackened when the smoke that is climbing up the outer walls finds the windows open.
author: Amma Syncletica
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He who obeys not the rudder will obey the reef.
author: Herve of Brittany
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Temperance is simply a disposition of the mind that sets bounds to the passions.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: That you may be able to know God, first know yourself.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Whenever we sit in the hairdresser’s chair to have our hair cut, we take the mirror and carefully examine the arrangement of every lock. … Yet of our soul, deformed and transformed into a wild beast … we haven’t even the least perception.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: O Lord my God … in Your sight I have become a riddle to myself.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In other living creatures the ignorance of themselves is natural, but in men it is vice. Severinus Dwell in the cell of self-knowledge in order to know God’s goodness.
author: Catherine of Siena
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The truth is, we never really know ourselves.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Wouldn’t it show great ignorance … if someone when asked who he was didn’t know, and didn’t know his father or mother or from what country he came? Well now, if this would be so extremely stupid, we are incomparably more so when we do not strive to know who we are.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We’ll never completely know ourselves if we don’t strive to know God. By gazing at His grandeur, we encounter our own lowliness; by looking at His purity, we see our own filth; by thinking on His humility, we see how far we are from being humble.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: You persist in being worldly, superficial, scatterbrained … because you are a coward. What is it but cowardice not to want to face yourself?
author: Josemaria Escriva
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Our self-will is so subtle and so deeply rooted within us, so covered with excuses and defended by false reasoning, that it seems to be a demon. When we cannot do our own will in one way, we do it in another, under all kinds of pretexts.
author: Catherine of Genoa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We have to serve God in His way, not in ours.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If we wish to make any progress in the service of God, we must begin every day of our life with new ardor.
author: Charles Cardinal Borromeo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: What does it matter to a truly loving soul whether God be served by this means or by another?
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There is nothing small in the service of God.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God has created me to do Him some definite service; He has committed some work to me which He has not committed to another. I have my mission—I never may know it in this life, but I shall be told it in the next.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In the same way that a powerful medicine cures an illness, so illness itself is a medicine to cure passion. And there is much profit of soul in bearing illness quietly and giving thanks to God.
author: Amma Syncletica
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When we are sick, then we begin truly to know ourselves; then pain brings us home to ourselves; then we think how merry a thing it would be to pray in good health, though we can’t do that now because of our grief. … Then we think within ourselves, that if ever we recover and mend in body, we will amend in soul, leave all vices, and be virtuously occupied for the rest of our life. For that reason, we should be, when we are healthy, as we think we would be when we are sick.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When the Lord knows that good health is necessary for our welfare, He sends it to us; and when we need sickness, He sends that too.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Make sickness itself a prayer.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The prayer of the sick person is his patience and his acceptance of his sickness for the love of Jesus Christ.
author: Charles of Sezze
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Truly sickness is a great God-given grace. It makes us discover who we are.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Regarding a grave illness: He who has made me, unmakes me.
author: Eugenie Smet
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He accomplishes more by his silence than others that talk to no purpose.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Silence is a gift of God, to let us speak more intimately with Him.
author: Vincent Pallotti
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Be sober and hard-working men; avoid all vanity of dress that will exclude you from heaven; try to keep to the simplicity of manners of our fathers.
author: Nicholas of Flue
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Craftiness is the accumulation of artifices, intrigues, deceits, and appearances to mislead the minds of those with whom we converse. This is quite the reverse of simplicity, which requires that the outside should correspond with what is inside.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God in His nature is most simple and cannot admit of any duplicity. If we then would be conformed to Him, we should try to become by virtue what He is by nature. We should be simple in our affections, intentions, actions, and words; we should do what we find to do without artifice or guile, being on the outside what we are on the inside.
author: Vincent de Paul
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I detest dissimulation. What I have in my heart I have also on my tongue.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: What leper, when he has been healed, turns again and desires to have his leprosy back? You have put off your transgressions in baptism—forsake them!
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The end of sin is death.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Committing sin estranges us from God and puts us in league with the Devil.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The condemnation of those who know and yet do not apply their knowledge is the more severe; but even sin committed in ignorance is not without risk.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Whoever is drawn into sin against his will should understand that, because he allowed himself to be mastered by another sin committed previously, he is now, as a consequence of this first sin, led into another against his will.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Often God gives a man over to evil works as punishment for his past deeds of wickedness.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Sins that are easiest to amend bring the greatest punishment.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Prosperous sinners fare worst of all in the end.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There is only one thing to be feared … only one trial, and that is sin. … All the rest is beside the point, whether you talk of plots, feuds, betrayals, slanders, abuses, accusations, confiscations of property, exile, sharpened swords, open sea, or universal war. Whatever they may be, they are all fugitive and they will perish. They touch the mortal body, but wreak no harm on the watchful soul.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The sinner is not cast out; he casts himself out.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We avoid the eyes of men to commit sin, yet we do it in God’s presence.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Sin for man is a disorder and perversion: that is, a turning away from the most worthy Creator and a turning toward the inferior things that He has created.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Sins, however great and detestable they may be, are looked upon as trivial, or not as sins at all, when men get accustomed to them; and so far does this go, that such sins are not only not concealed, but are boasted of, and published far and wide. … In our own times, many forms of sin … are now so openly and habitually practiced that we dare not excommunicate a layman, we dare not even defrock a clergyman, for the commission of them.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Every sin is more harmful to the sinner than to the one sinned against.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: All sin is a kind of lying.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We may not sin in order to prevent someone else from sinning.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A sin that is not quickly blotted out by repentance is both a sin and a cause of sin.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Sin becomes much more scandalous when the sinner is honored for his position.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The goodness of God knows how to use our disordered wishes and actions, often lovingly turning them to our advantage while always preserving the beauty of His order.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To sin is nothing else than not to render God His due.
author: Anselm of Canterbury
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The life of sin is a fall from coherence into chaos; the life of virtue a climb from the many to the One.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The body of a sinner is a tomb, covering a soul dead by sin.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There are two sides to every sin: the turning of the will toward fleeting satisfaction and the turning away from everlasting value. As regards the first, the principle of all sins can be called lust—lust in its most general sense, namely, the unbridled desire for one’s own pleasure. As regards the second, the principle is pride—pride in its general sense, the lack of submission to God.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To sin is human, but to persist in sin is devilish.
author: Catherine of Siena
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Devil’s primary enterprise and proudest triumph consists in the bringing of a man to abuse that thing which is best in his own nature.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Among all the circumstances surrounding an evil deed it is hard to find one more hateful to God than the perversion of the real nature of good things to make them into instruments of our malice.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Just as water extinguishes fire, so love wipes away sin.
author: John of God
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Sin is a cruel murder, a frightful act of God-murder, a ghastly annihilation of all things. It is murder because it is the only cause of death, both of the body and of the soul of man. It is God-murder because sin and the sinner caused Christ to die on the cross, and the sinner continues this crucifixion of Jesus, day by day, within himself.
author: John Eudes
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We have only one evil to fear, and that is sin.
author: Alphonsus Liguori
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: One must deal with some sinners as with snails: Put them first in cool water until they come out, and then cook them little by little before they realize what’s happening to them.
author: Anthony Mary Claret
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Enjoy yourself as much as you like—if only you keep from sin.
author: John Bosco
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t imitate those who deceive themselves by saying, “I will sin and then go to confession.” How do you know that you will have time to make your confession? Isn’t it madness to wound yourself, in the hope that a doctor will be found to heal the wound?
author: John Bosco
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Guard your eyes, since they are the windows through which sin enters the soul.
author: John Bosco
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Death, but not sin!
author: Dominic Savio
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We should all realize that no matter where or how a man dies, if he is in the state of mortal sin and does not repent, when he could have done so and did not, the Devil tears his soul from his body with such anguish and distress that only a person who has experienced it can appreciate it.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To her son, King St. Louis IX: Rather would I see you dead at my feet than stained with a mortal sin.
author: Queen Blanche of France
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: You should permit yourself to be tormented by every kind of martyrdom before you would allow yourself to commit a mortal sin.
author: King Louis IX of France
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Even if you are committing mortal sins, keep on praying, and I guarantee that you will reach the harbor of salvation.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To sing is to pray twice.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To sing is the work of a lover.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Song is the leap of mind in the eternal breaking out into sound.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The soul of one who serves God always swims in joy, always keeps holiday, and is always in the mood for singing.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We should not bear with sinners in silence.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We should tolerate association with sinners only for the purpose of recalling them to repentance, by every means short of committing sin ourselves. But when every form of solicitude has been applied in their regard, we should avoid those who persist in their evil ways.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: With love of the sinner, hatred of the sin.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: SISTERS—See Religious Life; Virgins, Consecrated The peculiar characteristic of slavery is to be always in fear.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He who is kind is free, even if he is a slave; he who is evil is a slave, even if he is a king.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Train hard together: wrestle together, run together, suffer together, rest together, rise together, as stewards in God’s house, members of His household, and His servants. Win the approval of the One in whose ranks you serve and from whom you draw your pay. Let none of you turn deserter. Let your baptism be your arms; your faith, your helmet; your love, your spear; your endurance, your armor. Let your good works be your deposits from your soldier’s wages, so that you may receive back all that you have been careful to save.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Refusing further service as a Roman soldier: I am a soldier of Christ: combat is not permitted to me.
author: Martin of Tours
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In Confirmation … we are enrolled by bishops, who are like the leaders in Christ’s army; the imposition of hands reminds us that virtue and strength come from Christ.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: What, then, does God watch with pleasure and delight? The man who is fighting for Him against riches, against the world, against hell, against himself.
author: Louis de Montfort
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Believe one who has tried: You shall find a fuller satisfaction in the woods than in books. The trees and the rocks will teach you what you cannot hear from the masters.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is good when a soul loves solitude; it’s a sign that it takes delight in God and enjoys speaking with Him.
author: Jane Frances de Chantal
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Aim at a great interior nakedness, poverty of spirit: keep yourself in true interior solitude, in the depth of essence of the soul, which is the same as saying: remain in the temple of your soul.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: You have to cast yourself into the abyss of that divine solitude. Love and be silent, be silent and love! What silence, what sacred silence, what deep and holy love!
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Sorrow is given us on purpose to cure us of sin.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: O Lord, You who use sorrow to teach, and wound us to heal, and kill us lest we die to You!
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Sorrow can be alleviated by good sleep, a bath, and a glass of wine.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: All the joys of this life are accompanied by sorrows: if they were not, we would grow too much absorbed in them.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: No picture can be drawn with only the brightest colors, nor harmony created only from treble notes. … Our whole life is tempered between sweet and sour, and we must look for a mixture of both.
author: Robert Southwell
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Know that this soul of yours is free, self-determining, the fairest work of God, made according to the image of its Creator, immortal because of God who makes it immortal, a living being, rational, imperishable, because of Him who has conferred these gifts; having power to do as it will.
author: Cyril of Jerusalem
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He has not only delivered us from sins, but has made us lovable. Just as if someone were to take a leper consumed by illness and disease, and by age and poverty and hunger, and were to turn him suddenly into a handsome youth surpassing all men by his beauty, shedding a bright sunbeam from his cheeks, yes, shaming the dazzling beams of the sun with the sparkle of his eyes; and then were to set him down in the flower of his age, and on top of that, array him in purple and a diadem and all the royal regalia: That is how God has decked out our soul, how beautiful and desirable and lovable He has made it.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Each soul is in itself a world of God, and each one voyages within His own heart; nor is he shipwrecked, if he dwells on the things that are worthy.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The soul is the inner face of man, by which we are known, that we may be regarded with love by our Maker.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Every holy soul is itself a heaven in a sense—a heaven with understanding for its sun, faith for its moon, and virtues for its stars, a heaven where God dwells, according to His faithful promise.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Understanding and love—that is, the knowledge of and delight in the truth —are, as it were, the two arms of the soul, with which it embraces and comprehends with all saints the length and breadth, the height and depth, that is, the eternity, the love, the goodness, and the wisdom of God.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We know we have souls. But we seldom consider the precious things that can be found in this soul, or who dwells within it, or its high value. Consequently, little effort is made to preserve its beauty. All our attention is taken up with the plainness of the diamond’s setting … that is, with these bodies of ours.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I knew well that I had a soul; but I did not understand the dignity of this soul, nor did I know who lodged within it, because my eyes were blinded by the vanities of this life, so that I was prevented from seeing Him. I think that, had I known then as I do now, that in this little palace of my soul so great a King is lodged, I would not have left Him alone so often, but at least sometimes I would have stayed with Him and been more careful to prepare a clean lodging for Him.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God dwells in a secret and hidden way in all souls, in their very substance, for if He did not, they could not exist at all.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: All the world together is not worth one soul.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When you love unseemly conversation, you prepare a feast for demons.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let your speech be brief and savory.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If you mock your fellow, you are the mouth of the devil. … A spacious dwelling for Satan is the man that mocks his neighbor; a palace of the enemy is the heart of the mocker.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: For a Christian, a promise is a debt.
author: Cyril of Jerusalem
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When you speak evil, even if it is true, that is still a crime.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Happy the man whose words issue from the Holy Spirit and not from himself.
author: Anthony of Padua
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: No idle word should be uttered. I understand a word to be idle when it serves no good purpose, either for myself or for another, and was not intended to do so.
author: Ignatius Loyola
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In all talking and conversation let something always be said of spiritual things, and so shall all idle words and evil speaking be avoided.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Never utter in your neighbor’s absence what you wouldn’t say in his presence. Mary Magdalene dei Pazzi Avoid those who in your presence aren’t ashamed to make use of scandalous words and double entendres.
author: John Bosco
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Receive counsel in everything you do, and you won’t be sorry when you’ve done it.
author: Benedict of Nursia
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He who wants to stand alone without the support of a master and guide will be like the tree that stands alone in a field without a caretaker. No matter how much the tree bears, passers-by will pick the fruit before it ripens.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The virtuous soul that is alone and without a master is like a lone burning coal; it will grow colder rather than hotter.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When the enemy of our human nature tempts a righteous soul with his deceits and seductions, he earnestly desires that they be received in secret and kept secret. But if we manifest them to a confessor, or to some other spiritual person who understands his wiles and malicious intentions, the evil one is quite vexed. He knows that he cannot succeed in his evil endeavor, once his evident tricks have been revealed.
author: Ignatius Loyola
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Would you walk in earnest toward devotion? Seek some good man who will guide you; this is the greatest of all words of advice.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There are so many souls that would attain sanctity if only they were well directed. Thérèse of Lisieux Discipline, the safeguard of hope, the bond of faith, the guide of the way of salvation, the stimulus and nourishment of good dispositions, the teacher of virtue, causes us to abide always in Christ, and to live continually for God, and to attain to the heavenly promises and to the divine rewards. To follow her is wholesome, and to turn away from her and neglect her is deadly.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Solitude, vigils in the night, manual labor, nakedness, reading, and the other disciplines—we know that their purpose is to free the heart from injury by bodily passions and to keep it free; they are to be the rungs of a ladder up which it may climb to perfect love. If by accident some right and needful occupation prevents us from keeping these acts of discipline, we should not be guilty of gloom or annoyance—for the aim of these acts is to drive away such faults. … None of these practices are of any profit at all if the purpose for which they are undertaken is lost.
author: Moses the Black
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Just as taking a walk, journeying on foot, and running are bodily exercises, so we call “spiritual exercises” every way of preparing and disposing the soul to rid itself of all inordinate attachments, and, after their removal, of seeking and finding the will of God in the disposition of our life for the salvation of our soul.
author: Ignatius Loyola
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A man might seem to confess the Lord and hear His words, yet if he does not obey the Lord’s commands, he is condemned—even if, by some divine concession, he is vouchsafed an endowment of spiritual gifts.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let us imitate what we shall one day be.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Even as a man just recovered from an illness walks on his journey only as far as is absolutely necessary, and then with pain and difficulty, so the repentant sinner treads in God’s ways heavily and slowly until, having attained the grace of devotion, he resembles the healthy and light-hearted traveler, who not only proceeds on his way, but runs and leaps with joy in the way of God’s commandments, hastening into the paths of His heavenly counsels and aspirations.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Life Himself came down to be slain; Bread came down to suffer hunger; the Way came down to endure weariness on His journey; the Fountain came down to experience thirst. Do you, then, refuse to work and to suffer?
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God said: Why do you never stop asking to taste of My delights, yet you refuse the tribulations?
author: Margaret of Cortona
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Suffering is a short pain and a long joy.
author: Henry Suso
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If God causes you to suffer much, it’s a sign that He has great designs for you, and that He certainly intends to make you a saint.
author: Ignatius Loyola
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Suffering out of love for God is better than working miracles.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The purest suffering bears and carries in its train the purest understanding.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: One must not think that a person who is suffering is not praying. He is offering up his sufferings to God, and many a time he is praying much more truly than one who goes away by himself and meditates his head off, and, if he has squeezed out a few tears, thinks that is prayer.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Blessed be He, who came into the world for no other purpose than to suffer.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Suffering is a great favor. Remember that everything soon comes to an end … and take courage. Think of how our gain is eternal.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The greatness of our God must be tested by the desire we have of suffering for His sake.
author: Philip Neri
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Surely nothing is too much for Him when there is a question of sanctifying a soul. He hands over the body and soul to weakness in order to purify them in contempt of earthly things and in the love of His Majesty. He wounds and He heals them; He crucifies them on His cross in order to glorify them in His glory; in short, He gives them death in order to have them live in eternity. Let us accept these appearances of evil in order to have the real goods they produce, and we will be happy both in this life and in the next.
author: Vincent de Paul
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Suffer and offer up those trifling injuries, those petty inconveniences, that daily befell you—this toothache, this headache, this cold, this contempt or scorn.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Suffering borne in the will quietly and patiently is a continual, very powerful prayer before God.
author: Jane Frances de Chantal
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The more we suffer, the more we are favored by God.
author: Jane Frances de Chantal
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Without misfortune, you might not have been wholly bad, but perhaps you might not have been entirely good, either.
author: Claude de la Colombiere
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When it is all over, you will not regret having suffered; rather you will regret having suffered so little, and suffered that little so badly.
author: Sebastian Valfre
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Do as the merchant does with his merchandise: Make a profit on every item. Don’t allow the loss of the tiniest fragment of the true cross. It may be only the sting of a horsefly or the prick of a pin that annoys you; it may be a neighbor’s little eccentricities, some unintended slight, the insignificant loss of a penny, some small restlessness of soul, a light pain in your limbs. Make a profit on every item as the grocer does, and you’ll soon be wealthy in God.
author: Louis de Montfort
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I would like to make everyone understand the great grace that God, in His mercy, bestows when He sends suffering, especially suffering devoid of consolation. Then indeed the soul is purified like gold in the furnace; without knowing it, it becomes radiant and is set free to take flight to its Good.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Those who suffer for the love of God help Jesus carry His cross, and if they persevere they will share His glory in heaven.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Say always, “My beloved and despised Redeemer, how sweet it is to suffer for You.”
author: Alphonsus Liguori
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There are people who make capital out of everything, even the winter. If it is cold, they offer their little sufferings to God.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The crosses we meet on the road to heaven are like a fine stone bridge on which you can cross a river. Christians who don’t suffer cross this river on a shaky bridge that’s always in danger of giving way under their feet.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Once they’ve been transformed in the flames of love, crosses are like a bundle of hawthorn that you throw on the fire, and that the fire reduces to ashes. The hawthorn is thorny, but the ashes are soft. Hawthorn exudes balm and the cross exudes sweetness. But you’ve got to press the thorns in your hands and clasp the cross to your heart if you want them to distill the essence they contain.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Can you expect to go to heaven for nothing? Did not our dear Savior track the whole way to it with His tears and blood? And yet you start at every little pain.
author: Elizabeth Ann Seton
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Suffering counts for more than work.
author: Anthony Mary Claret
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: As iron is fashioned by the fire and on an anvil, so in the fire of suffering and under the weight of trials, our souls receive the form that our Lord desires for them to have.
author: Madeleine Sophie Barat
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Thank the good God for having visited you through suffering. If we knew the value of suffering, we would ask for it.
author: Brother Andre Bessette
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In reference to our inability at times to find a meaningful pattern in God’s actions in our lives: We see the reverse side of the embroidery, because we are seated on a low stool.
author: Padre Pio Pietrelcina
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God sometimes allows us to be in such a profound darkness that not a single star shines in our skies. The reason is that we must be reminded that we are on earth only to suffer, while following our gentle Savior along a dark and thorny path.
author: Charles de Foucauld
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It would be the utmost folly for us to give up five and even six days to the business of this life, and yet not to devote so much as one day, or even one small part of a day, to spiritual things.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I entreat you, keep Sundays holy. Working on Sunday will not make you rich; on the contrary, you will bring down misfortunes on yourselves and your children.
author: Bernadette Soubirous
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It’s better to keep quiet and be a real Christian than to chatter and not be one.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t talk too much, not even with words that are wise; for even words that are wise, if they are too many, become wearisome.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Remarking on two monks who tended to say the first thing that came into their heads: Their house has no door. Whoever wants, goes into the stable and steals the donkey.
author: Antony the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Why, you words, did I let you go out? I have often been penitent that I spoke, but never that I kept silent.
author: Arsenius the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: How can we guard our heart if our tongue leaves the door of the fortress open? Sisois Let your words be few when in the midst of many.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If we say less than we should, it is easy to add; but having said too much, it is hard to take it away.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The love of talk distracts all the powers of our soul from God, and fills them with earthly objects and impressions, like a vessel of water which cannot be clear and settled while you are continually stirring the earthy particles from the bottom.
author: Elizabeth Ann Seton
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Speak little to creatures but speak much with God. He will make you truly wise.
author: Mary Mazarello
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is good to teach, if the one who teaches also acts.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is dangerous for a man to try teaching before he is trained in the good life. A man whose house is about to fall down may invite travelers inside to refresh them, but instead they are hurt in the collapse of the house. It is the same with teachers who have not carefully trained themselves in the good life: They ruin their hearers as well as themselves. Their mouth invites to salvation, their way of life leads to ruin.
author: Amma Syncletica
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t suppose that anyone really learns something from another human being. I can admonish you by the sound of my voice, but if there isn’t within you One who teaches, then my words are only meaningless noise. … The instruction that comes from others is a kind of help, a call for attention. But the One who truly teaches the heart teaches from heaven.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Teaching unsupported by grace may enter our ears, but it never reaches the heart. When God’s grace does touch our innermost minds to bring understanding, then His Word, which is received by the ear, can sink deep into the heart.
author: Isidore of Seville
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: All who undertake to teach must be endowed with deep love, the greatest patience and, most of all, profound humility. The Lord will find them worthy to become fellow workers with Him in the cause of truth.
author: Joseph of Calasanza
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is chiefly by asking questions and in provoking explanations that the master must open the mind of the pupil, make him work, and use his thinking powers, form his judgment, and make him find out for himself the answer.
author: Jean Baptiste de la Salle Jesus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Christ, in His infinite wisdom, used the words and idioms that were in use among those whom He addressed. You should do likewise.
author: Joseph Cafasso
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In your strife with the Devil, you have for spectators the angels and the Lord of angels.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To those who are just and upright, temptations become helps.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: As the pilot of a vessel is tried in the storm; as the wrestler is tried in the ring; the soldier in the battle, and the hero in adversity: so is the Christian tried in temptation.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When we are tempted to utter a sinful word, or when we find ourselves being carried away by anger or some other such passion, let us reflect on what privileges we have been granted, what Spirit it is whose presence we enjoy, and this thought will check in us those unruly passions.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The Devil tempts so that he may ruin; God tempts so that He may crown.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: For the Devil does not seduce or influence anyone, unless he finds him ready in some part similar to himself. He finds him coveting something, and greed opens the door for the Devil’s suggestion to enter.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The tempter, ever on the lookout, wages war most violently against those whom he sees most careful to avoid sin.
author: Pope Leo the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Close your ears to the whisperings of hell and bravely oppose its onslaughts.
author: Clare of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He did not say: You will not be troubled—you will not be tempted—you will not be distressed. But He said: You will not be overcome.
author: Julian of Norwich
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: All the temptations of hell cannot stain a soul that does not love them.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is not always in the soul’s power not to feel a temptation. But it is always in its power not to consent to it.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We must take to heart, brothers, from what stuff we were created, who we were and what kind of creatures we were when we entered the world, as if from a tomb and from utter darkness. Having prepared for us bountifully before we were born, He who fashioned us and created us brought us into His world. Since, then, we owe all this to Him, we ought to give Him thanks for everything.
author: Pope Clement
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I Be eager for more frequent gatherings for thanksgiving to God and His glory. For when we meet in this way, the forces of Satan are rendered powerless and his destructive power is canceled in the concord of your faith.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When you lie down on your bed, remember with thanksgiving the blessings and the providence of God.
author: Antony the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We should not accept in silence the benefactions of God, but return thanks for them.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Thanking is a new, inward knowing, with great reverence and loving awe.
author: Julian of Norwich
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: One act of thanksgiving when things go wrong with us is worth a thousand thanks when things are agreeable to our inclination.
author: John of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In all created things discern the providence and wisdom of God, and in all things give Him thanks.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If we have any natural defect, either in mind or body, let us not grieve and be sorry for ourselves. Who is there that ever receives a gift and tries to make bargains about it? Let us, then, return thanks for what He has bestowed on us. Who can tell whether, if we had had a larger share of ability or stronger health, we would have possessed them to our destruction?
author: Alphonsus Liguori
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Alas, yet if I am not one of His elect, it is only I to be blamed, and when going down [to hell] I must still lift the hands to the very last look in praise and gratitude for what He has done to save me. What more could He have done?
author: Elizabeth Ann Seton
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The purpose of theology is threefold: to refute error, to teach sound morals, and to contemplate truth.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Love is the abridgment of all theology.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let them innovate in nothing, but keep the traditions.
author: Pope Stephen
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I “Guard,” says [the Apostle Paul], “what has been committed” [1 Tim 6:20]. What does it mean? … It is what has been faithfully entrusted to you, not what has been discovered by you; what you have received, not what you have thought up; a matter not of ingenuity, but of doctrine; not of private acquisition, but of public Tradition; a matter brought to you, not put forth by you, in which you must not be the author but the guardian, not the founder but the sharer, not the leader, but the follower.
author: Vincent of Lerins
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To ask questions such as these, and to make such guesses as we can at the answers, is a useful exercise for the intellect, if the discussion be kept within proper bounds, and if we avoid the error of supposing ourselves to know what we do not know. For what is the necessity of affirming, or denying, or defining with accuracy on these subjects, when we may without blame be entirely ignorant of them?
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Thoughts inevitably besiege the mind. But any earnest person has the power to accept or reject them. Their origin is in some ways outside ourselves, but whether to choose them or not lies within us.
author: Moses the Black
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Just as you cannot stop air from coming into your chest, you cannot stop evil thoughts from coming into your mind. Your part is to resist them.
author: Abba Poemen
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If you shut a snake or a scorpion in a box, in the end it will die. And wicked thoughts that the demons scatter slowly lose their power if the victim has endurance.
author: Abba Poemen
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Men have the power of thinking so that they may avoid sin.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Thought is a kind of sight of the mind.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Occupy your minds with good thoughts, or the enemy will fill them with bad ones. Unoccupied, they cannot be.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In thought, there are two ways of sinning mortally. The first is to consent to the evil thought with the intention of carrying it out, or of doing so if one can. The second way of sinning mortally is actually carrying out the sin to which consent was given.
author: Ignatius Loyola
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If any bad thought comes to you, make the sign of the cross, or say an Our Father, or strike your breast, and try to think of something else. If you do that, the thought will actually be winning you merit, because you will be resisting it.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A single human thought is worth more than the whole world; hence, God alone is worthy of being its subject.
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A Christian is not his own master, since all his time belongs to God.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Time takes no holidays.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Do now—do now—what you’ll wish you had done when your moment comes to die.
author: Angela Merici
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Since, when the hour of reckoning comes, you’ll be sorry for not having used this time in the service of God, why don’t you arrange and use it now as you would wish you’d done if you were dying?
author: John of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When death comes, the mighty messenger of God, no king can command him, no authority can restrain him, no riches can hire him to wait past his appointed time even one moment of an hour. Therefore let us consider well in time what words we are bound to speak and what deeds we are bound to do, and let us say them and do them quickly. And let us leave unsaid and undone all superfluous things (and, much more, all damnable things), knowing well that we have no empty time allowed to us.
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: “These are bad times,” people are saying, “troublesome times!” If only our lives were all good, our times would be good, for we ourselves make our times—as we are, so are our times. But what can we do? After all, we cannot convert the mass of humanity to a good life. But let the few who do listen to the will of God live good lives; and let the few who live good lives endure the many who do not. The good are the wheat, still on the threshing floor; and though the chaff lies with them there, the chaff will not come with them to the bam.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Truly, matters in the world are in a bad state; but if you and I begin in earnest to reform ourselves, a really good beginning will have been made.
author: Peter of Alcantara
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Even if the apostles had not left their writings to us, ought we not to follow the rule of the tradition that they handed down to those to whom they committed the churches?
author: Irenaeus of Lyons
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
