source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is needful also to make use of Tradition, for not everything can be gotten from sacred Scripture. The holy Apostles handed down some things in the Scriptures, other things in Tradition.
author: Epiphanius of Salamis
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Of the dogmas and preaching preserved in the Church, some we possess from written teaching and others we receive from the tradition of the Apostles, handed on to us in mystery. In respect to piety, both are of the same force.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: “Therefore, brethren, stand fast and hold the traditions that you have been taught, whether by word or by our letter” [2 Th 2:15]. From this it is clear that they did not hand down everything by letter, but there was much also that was not written. Like that which was written, the unwritten too is worthy of belief. So let us regard the tradition of the Church also as worthy of belief. Is it a tradition? Inquire no further.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Keep the talent of the Catholic faith inviolate and unimpaired. What has been faithfully entrusted, let it remain in your possession, let it be handed on by you. You have received gold, so give gold. For my part, I do not want you to substitute one thing for another; I do not want you impudently to put lead in place of gold, or, fraudulently, brass. I do not want the appearance of gold, but the real thing.
author: Vincent of Lerins
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A small thing is not small when it leads to something great; and it is no small matter to forsake the ancient tradition of the Church that was upheld by all those who were called before us, whose conduct we should observe, and whose faith we should imitate.
author: John of Damascus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A single opinion cannot overturn the unanimous tradition of the whole Church, which has spread to the end of the earth.
author: John of Damascus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We do not advocate one thing at one time and change it at another; otherwise the faith would become a joke to those outside.
author: John of Damascus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In the midst of adversities, I desire prosperous days; in the midst of prosperity, I dread adversity. Between these two, is there no middle ground where the life of man is not a trial?
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I pray God may open your eyes and let you see what hidden treasures He bestows on us in the trials from which the world thinks only to flee.
author: John of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We always find that those who walked closest to Christ, our Lord, were those who had to bear the greatest trials.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Since gold and silver, which are only corruptible metals, are purified and tested by fire, it is but reasonable that our faith, which surpasses all the riches of the world, should be tried.
author: Peter Claver
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God wishes to test you like gold in the furnace. The dross is consumed by the fire, but the pure gold remains and its value increases.
author: Jerome Emiliani
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I believe in one God, the Source of all things, without beginning, uncreated, immortal and unassailable, eternal, everlasting, incomprehensible, bodiless, invisible, uncircumscribed, without form. I believe in one superessential Being, one Godhead greater than our conception of divinity, in three Persons: Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, and I adore Him alone. I worship one God, one Godhead, but I adore three Persons: God the Father, God the Son made flesh, and God the Holy Spirit, one God.
author: John of Damascus
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The high might of the Trinity is our father, and the deep wisdom of the Trinity is our mother, and the great love of the Trinity is our Lord.
author: Julian of Norwich
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: All shall be well, and all shall be well, and all manner of things shall be well.
author: Julian of Norwich
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I am afraid that if we begin to put our trust in human help, some of our Divine help will fail us.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Consider seriously how quickly people change, and how little trust is to be had in them; and hold fast to God, who does not change.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We shall steer safely through every storm, as long as our heart is right, our intention fervent, our courage steadfast, and our trust fixed in God.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The past must be abandoned to God’s mercy, the present to our faithfulness, the future to divine providence.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Entrust yourself entirely to God. He is a Father and a most loving Father at that, who would rather let heaven and earth collapse than abandon anyone who trusted in Him.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: With the confidence of a son, rest in the care and love that divine Providence has for you in all your needs. Look upon Providence as a child does its mother who loves him tenderly. You can be sure that God loves you incomparably more.
author: Jane Frances de Chantal
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Whatever good or evil befalls you, be confident that God will convert it all to your good.
author: Jane Frances de Chantal
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The more you abandon to God the care of all temporal things, the more He will take care to provide for all your wants; but if, on the contrary, you try to supply all your own needs, Providence will allow you to continue to do just that, and then it may very well happen that even necessities will be lacking, God thus reproving you for your lack of faith and reliance on Him.
author: Jean Baptiste de la Salle
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: He who trusts in himself is lost. He who trusts in God can do all things.
author: Alphonsus Liguori
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Whatever, wherever I am, I can never be thrown away. If I am in sickness, my sickness may serve Him; if I am in sorrow, my sorrow may serve Him. … He does nothing in vain; He may prolong my life, He may shorten it; He knows what He is about. He may take away my friends, He may throw me among strangers, He may make me feel desolate, make my spirits sink, hide the future from me—still He knows what He is about.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I have started houses with no more than the price of a loaf of bread and prayers, for with Him who comforts me, I can do anything.
author: Frances Xavier Cabrini
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The heart of God invites all to put it to the proof. The more He gives, the more He desires to give. He loves to see the trust that makes us persist in knocking unceasingly.
author: Placid Riccardi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: All truth, wherever it is found, belongs to us as Christians.
author: Justin Martyr
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: No one is truly poor but except the one who lacks the truth.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Truth is one; contradictions of the truth are manifold.
author: Cyril of Jerusalem
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Those who wage war against the truth are powerless to win; rather, they wound themselves, like those who kick against spikes.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We must have such great love for the truth that our words will take on the character of oaths.
author: Paulinus of Nola
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I invoke You, O God, the Truth—in whom and from whom and through whom all things are true that anywhere are true.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Nothing conquers except truth; the victory of truth is charity.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: People hate the truth for the sake of whatever it is they love more than the truth. They love truth when it shines warmly on them, and hate it when it rebukes them.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: O God of truth, I seek that I may receive, so that my joy may be full. Till then, let my mind meditate on it, and let my tongue speak of it; let my heart love it, and the words of my mouth be about it.
author: Anselm of Canterbury
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Truth is the identity of thought and thing.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: What God’s Son has told me, I take for truth. Truth Himself speaks truly, or else there is nothing true.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Every truth without exception—no matter who may utter it—is from the Holy Spirit.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Truth suffers, but never dies.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In Him, therefore, do I understand and possess all truth that is in heaven and earth and hell, and in all creatures; and so great is the truth and the certainty that were the whole world to declare the contrary, I would not believe it— indeed, I would mock it.
author: Angela of Foligno
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Those who are led by the Holy Spirit have true ideas; that’s why so many ignorant people are wiser than the learned.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Truth is one; therefore … the multitude of men are wrong, as far as they differ; and as they differ, not about trivial points, but about great matters, it follows that the multitude of men, whether by their own fault or not, are wrong even in the greater matters of religion.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Error may flourish for a time, but truth will prevail in the end. The only effect of error ultimately is to promote truth.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Chosen by himself to be written on his gravestone: From shadows and symbols to the truth.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Let no one be deceived: Even the heavenly beings, the splendor of the angels, the principalities, both seen and unseen, if they fail to believe in the blood of Christ, are damned.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There are two kinds of coins, one God’s, the other the world’s. Each bears its own stamp: unbelievers that of this world; believers, who are spurred by love, the stamp of God the Father through Jesus Christ.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: These days no one thinks of the fears that the future holds; no one takes to heart the day of judgment, and the wrath of God; the punishments to come upon unbelievers, and the eternal torments decreed for the faithless. Whatever a conscience would fear if it believed, our conscience, because it no longer believes, doesn’t fear at all. If only it believed, it would take heed; and if it took heed, it would escape.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: No one is so foolish as not to believe that the things of the physical world are subject to someone’s government, providence, and disposition, seeing that they are regulated according to a certain order and time. Thus we see the sun, the moon, and the stars and other parts of the physical world all holding a certain course, which would not happen if they were the sport of chance. For that reason, a man would be a fool not to believe in God.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Unbelievers call themselves rational; not because they decide by evidence, but because, after they have made their decision, they merely occupy themselves in sifting it.
author: John Henry Cardinal Newman
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Your accord and harmonious love is a hymn to Jesus Christ. Yes, you should form all together one choir, so that, in perfect harmony and taking your pitch from God, you may sing with one voice to the Father through Jesus Christ, that He may listen to you and know you from your chant as the canticle of His only Son.
author: Ignatius of Antioch
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The time will come when there will be one flock and one shepherd, one faith and one dear knowledge of God.
author: Bridget of Sweden
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The entire universe pre-exists in the Godhead, which is its primordial cause. Father, Son, and Holy Spirit are all in all, because in their divinity every other thing is anticipated and possessed.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The entire universe is one dominion and realm, governed by one Ruler, who is the First Mover, the First Truth, the First Good—God, blessed forever and ever.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: God is an artist, and the universe is His work of art.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Nothing, nothing is baser than the usury of this world, nothing more cruel. Why, such a man traffics in the calamities of others; he makes himself gains from others’ distress; he demands wages for kindness as though he were afraid to seem merciful. Under the cloak of kindness he digs the pitfall deeper; by his help, he galls a man’s poverty; in the act of stretching out a hand, he thrusts him down; and when receiving him in harbor, he sends him to shipwreck.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We should let God be the One to praise us and not praise ourselves. For God detests those who commend themselves. Let others applaud our good deeds.
author: Pope Clement
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: I If you put wax in front of a fire, it melts; and if you pour vain praises on the soul, it goes soft and weak in seeking goodness.
author: Amma Syncletica
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If you glory in yourself and not in the Lord, you will be kissing your own hand instead of the hand of your Benefactor.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The desire to be well-thought-of—what is it other than a desire for different treatment from what was accorded to the Son of God? How was He content to be regarded by the people? As a madman, a rebel, a fool, a sinner. … Vanity shoots up and will grow strong if we do not crush it and look solely for the glory of God, for which only we must work.
author: Vincent de Paul
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: To prefer man to God: a strange and unhappy slavery is that of a man who seeks to please other men. … I vow never to do anything nor to leave anything undone because of what people think. … It will set up in me a great interior peace.
author: Claude de la Colombiere
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Vice mimics virtue.
author: Cyril of Jerusalem
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: This is the definition of vice: the wrong use, in violation of the Lord’s commandment, of what has been given us by God for a good purpose.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We make a ladder of our vices when we trample them underfoot.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Vice is contrary to human nature, because it is against the order of reason.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When we are assailed by some vice we must, as far as possible, embrace the practice of the contrary virtue.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The crown of victory is promised only to those who engage in the struggle.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: You can fight with confidence when you are sure of victory. With Christ and for Christ, victory is certain.
author: Bernard of Clairvaux
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Virgins … are the flowers of the Church, the beauty and ornament of spiritual grace, a subject of joy, a perfect and unsullied homage of praise and honor, the image of God corresponding to the sanctity of the Lord, the most illustrious portion of Christ’s flock. In them the glorious fecundity of our mother the Church finds expression, and she rejoices; the more the number of virgins increase, the greater is this mother’s joy.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A consecrated virgin ought not only to be so, but also to be perceived and believed to be so: No one on seeing a consecrated virgin should be in any doubt as to whether she is one.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The soul feeds on the virtues.
author: Gregory of Nyssa
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Where virtue is, there are many snares.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: So good a thing is virtue that even its enemies applaud and admire it.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Virtue is nothing but well-directed love.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Virtue makes a good use even of the evils a man suffers.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: No wickedness, no heresy, not even the Devil himself can deceive anyone without counterfeiting virtue.
author: Dorotheos of Gaza
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The essence of virtue consists in the doing of what is good rather than what is difficult.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: O glorious virtue! Who would not give himself to death a thousand times, and endure any suffering through desire, to win you? You are a queen who possesses the entire world; you inhabit the enduring life; for the soul that is arrayed in you is yet mortal, you make it abide by force of love with those who are immortal.
author: Catherine of Siena
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Everyone argues in favor of the virtue he practices easily, and exaggerates the difficulties of the virtues that are contrary to it.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: True virtue has no limits.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: In the case of the virtues, sir, it is very easy to pass from defect to excess, from being righteous to being rigorous and rashly zealous. It is said that good wine easily turns to vinegar.
author: Vincent de Paul
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Virtue demands courage, constant effort, and, above all, help from on high.
author: John Vianney
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Whoever has been called to the preaching of the Gospel should obey instantly and without delay.
author: Basil the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Each state in life has its special duties; by their accomplishments one may find happiness in the world as well as in solitude; for not all are called to separate themselves from the society of men.
author: Nicholas of Flue
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: A good vocation is simply a firm and constant will in which the person who is called must serve God in the way and in the places to which almighty God has called him.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If a person shows a firm and persevering determination to serve God in the manner and place to which His divine majesty calls her, she gives the best proof we can have that she has a true vocation.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Just as every sort of gem when cast into honey becomes brighter and more sparkling, so each person becomes more acceptable and fitting in his own vocation when he sets that vocation in the context of devotion. Through devotion family cares become more peaceful, mutual love between husband and wife becomes more sincere, the service we owe the prince becomes more faithful, and our work, no matter what it is, becomes more pleasant and agreeable.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The grace of even wishing to belong to God must come from Himself.
author: Elizabeth Ann Seton
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Our Lord has created persons for all states in life, and in all of them we see people who have achieved sanctity by fulfilling their obligations well.
author: Anthony Mary Claret
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: At last I have found my vocation: My vocation is love. Thérèse of Lisieux For a war to be just, three conditions are necessary: public authority, just cause, right motive.
author: Thomas Aquinas
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Your weaknesses and deficiencies ought to make you humble, but you should also throw all of them into the fire of the love of God, where they will be devoured and consumed like a straw mattress thrown into a great furnace.
author: Paul of the Cross
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Consider God’s generosity toward you rather than your own unworthiness in His sight, and live in His strength, rather than in thoughts of your own weakness.
author: Vincent de Paul
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: You say that you are wealthy and rich, and you think that you should make use of those things that God has willed you should possess. Use them certainly, but for the things of salvation; use them, but for good purposes; use them, but for those things that God has commanded and that the Lord has set forth. Let the poor feel that you are wealthy; let the needy feel that you are rich. Lend your estate to God; give food to Christ.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Not everything that can be done ought to be done. … If you think that God gave you riches for the sole purpose of enjoying them thoroughly yourself —without using them for the purposes of salvation—then you’re sinning against God. For God gave us a voice, too, but that doesn’t mean we must use it to sing indecent love songs. And God willed that iron be mined from the earth, but not so that we would murder one another with weapons crafted from it.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: How can they follow Christ when they are held back by the chains of their wealth? Or how can they seek heaven, and climb to sublime and lofty heights, when they are weighed down by earthly desires? They think that they possess, but they themselves are possessed—slaves of their profit; the bond slaves, not the lords, of their own money.
author: Cyprian of Carthage
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The rich man lies awake; his riches chase away his sleep. While his dogs sleep, he guards his treasure from the thieves.
author: Ephraem the Syrian
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Nothing is more false than wealth. It is a hostile comrade, a domestic enemy.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If you would rise, shun luxury, for luxury lowers and degrades.
author: John Chrysostom
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Renunciation of riches is the origin and preserver of virtues.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Riches are the instrument of all vices, because they render us capable of putting into execution even our worst desires.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We are born into this world naked, we leave it without a cent, we are buried without our inheritance.
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: The earth was made for all, rich and poor, in common. Why do you rich claim it as your exclusive right?
author: Ambrose of Milan
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Opulence is always the result of theft, if not committed by the actual possessor, then by his predecessor. Jerome Why would you rejoice in silver? Either your silver will perish, or you will, and no one knows which will perish first. Only one thing is certain: both shall perish.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: All the abundance I have that is not my God is only poverty.
author: Augustine of Hippo
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t be anxious about what you have, but about what you are.
author: Pope Gregory the Great
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: We should have no more use or regard for money in any of its forms than we have for dust. Those who think it is worth more, or who are greedy for it, expose themselves to the danger of being deceived by the Devil.
author: Francis of Assisi
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: How proud we are of gold and silver, which are actually no part of ourselves, but rather are part of the earth—things that are by their nature no better than copper or tin, and much less useful than the poor metal that is used to make the ploughshare, and horseshoes, and horse nails. How proud many men are of those glistening precious stones, of which the very brightest, even if it costs many dollars, will never shine half so bright nor show half so much light as a poor half-penny candle!
author: Thomas More
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Our greatest gain is to lose the wealth that is of such brief duration and, by comparison with eternal things, of such little worth; yet we get upset about it and our gain turns to loss.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Of what use are riches in eternity?
author: Aloysius Gonzaga
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Pharmacists have almost all kinds of poison for their use, as circumstances may require, but they are not poisoned, because they keep their poisons not in their bodies, but in their shops. In like manner you may possess riches without being poisoned by them, provided you have them for use in your house or your purse, and not, by loving them, in your heart.
author: Francis de Sales
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: It is not a sin to have riches, but to fix our hearts upon them.
author: Jean Baptiste de la Salle
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: If God allows some people to pile up riches instead of making themselves poor as Jesus did, it is so they may use what He has entrusted to them as loyal servants, in accordance with the Master’s will, to do spiritual and temporal good to others.
author: Charles de Foucauld
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: Don’t forget it: He has much who needs least. Don’t create necessities for yourself.
author: Josemaria Escriva
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: There’s no such thing as bad weather. All weather is good because it’s God’s.
author: Teresa of Avila
source_title: A Dictionary of Quotes from the Saints
source_file: A Dictionary of Quotes From th - Thigpen, Paul_6247.pdf

quote: When she asked why the wicked often prosper, God said to her: If I gave temporal goods only to my friends, the wicked would despair and the good would grow proud. Therefore, temporal goods are given to all so that I, the Creator and Giver of all, may be loved by all.
